description:
A neighborhood gem in Laurel Heights, this place would be on my weekly restaurant list if I lived in the area. 

Everything from the service, to the wine list, to the food, to the desserts, to the SERVICE. What a great experience. 

Three of us for dinner, two of us wanted to share a primi and a secondi. They split the plates and delivered them in a perfectly sequenced way. 

The food was spectacular. We tried the tortellini that everyone raves about - the hay and straw - so good. The Veal with mushrooms. DELISH and the chicken milanese - so good. The carpaccio and a few salads rounded out the meal... but dessert! 

The tiramisu was big enough for the table of three. HUGE slide and it was wonderfully decadent. 

And a side note. Lots of people from the neighborhood were there. You could tell because it was like Cheers - where everyone knows their names. The staff dotted on some of the older ladies who were in attendance that night. Helped them to their seats and helped them as they left. It was so comforting to see the staff treat everyone who entered like they were a special guest. 

Next time in SF - I will search this lovely haven out and drag some friends along with me.
author: Marilyn D.

description:
Osteria has been a fixture in the Presidio Heights  Neighborhood for decades....and that says something as to how well they run a restaurant!!!

It is a very warm and quaint place to get a good classic Italian meal. Nicely executed appetizers, pastas, meats, and desserts.

Services is warm and efficient. Prices are what you would expect for San Francisco and classic Italian fare.

Food is good not great but it is always consistent.

The three of us had:
Bruschetta : crostini served with mozzarella, marinated chopped tomatoes, minced garlic and fennel ( It is good but not something amazing and at $13 somewhat overpriced)

The three salads were all okay: The Cesar was very pedestrian, as was the house salad. 

The only unique salad was my friend's brother's salad : the spinach salad which was really good ( spinach, feta, roasted almonds, peanuts and mushrooms with balsamic vinaigrette:  A very unique blend of items and tastes).

My friend Michele and I both had the tagliarini contadina (spinach pasta with chicken, tomatoes and shiitake mushrooms). It is well executed but pretty pedestrian.

The Salmon (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=juEiq2XuppveJouPqwOesw&userid=kroQYWSj-BhIEXT4VwLRHA) looked fine but was very pedestrian as well.

Overall Osteria is a fine place to get a classic, consistent, yet uninspired Italian meal.
author: David G.

description: Wonderful neighborhood restaurant, great quality food with a relaxed vibe.  The staff remembers you and what you like.  My favorites are the minestrone soup (best i've ever had), and the gnocchi.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
Very impressive food and service.  It's a typical small family restaurant with people who welcome you sincerely, are happy you're there, and who know how to cook.  Highly recommended. 
Merritt Weisinger
author: Merritt W.

description: As always, lovely staff and made to order food. Fresh and homemade pasta. If isn't on the menu, they will try to make it for you. The scampi superb and the gnocchi with bolognese is heaven. This is a small family style restaurant that never fails.  We drive from Reno, Nevada -- just to eat here.
author: Leanh E.

description:
This place has been a favorite from when we lived in SF
We were staying in the area and decided to go back
It's as good as ever
Fun local
Place for delicious food
author: Mary Ann C.

description:
I have lived 2 blocks from this place for over 10 years.  It was a Saturday night and we wanted some grub and had made no plans.

I thought of this place - called them and they said we could come over at 8pm. 

We arrived and though the place was packed - we got seated right away, in the back - 1 table away from the kitchen.

Service was good. The wine prices are steep. The cheapest was about $14/glass or triple that for a bottle.

My man & I split the Carpaccio (really excellent - a bit too much red onion - but the beef was great.

For entree's we split the veal with mushrooms and the tortellini with cream and peas.
The veal was a bit too thin - so I think there should have been more of it.  The pasta hit the spot...that spot where you crave very fattening pasta.

At the suggestion of the two ladies next to us we got their lemon cheesecake. it was very light and tart.

I think $150 total so kinda pricey

...we waddled out.
author: Amy W.

description:
I have gone for 20 years - I remember the original owner and chef. He's not there anymore - he died, and the wait staff is different. 

The food is still great, though. Simple, seems like the same recipes, and it's reassuring and comforting to eat here - so many places change and go downhill. Osteria has kept its allure for me. 

Their salad dressing on the radicchio / watercress / arugula still kicks ass. I can't find dressing that good anywhere else
author: tom p.

description: A very nice neighborhood spot, with an owner to greet you and remember your name to thank you as you leave. Solid Italian food, simply prepared.  Wine list was short but well-chosen. Didn't see any cocktails being served. Veal picatta was nice as was the bruschetta.
author: Lee P.

description: So tonight it was just my 90 year old dad and me for dinner. I have had many a meal with my family but for whatever reason this meal was one of the best ever. We come to this restaurant often but tonight was over the top. Minestrone is always good. The Tucson melon with pots churro was without question the best; the melon was so sweet and the porsciutto was incredibly delicious. Salmon was next and it was absolutely delicious. It was with a wine and tomato sauce, truly outstanding. Dessert was a flourless chocolate cake with strawberries, and a panacota with strawberries. Truly outstanding
author: Stephen B.

description: Nice neighborhood restaurant. The service was great, the food was very good. We ordered artichoke bottoms with shrimp which was very fresh, gnocchi which was delicate and delicious, and veal scallopini with mushrooms which was also very good. Helpful to have reservations because this is a very popular spot. Great menu, service, cozy and warm. We will be back.
author: Adia L.

description: This is a family-owned business that has been open for years yet still has the owner on site nearly every night.  Their food is consistently good and they are happy to answer questions and direct you to ordering the items that are best suited for what you like.  (For me, it's the healthy side.  I loved the spinach salad and also a pasta with chicken breast--and the staff was right--it was enough to bring some home : )  I thought the pinot noir was very good as well.  I personally like to patronize small family-run businesses and to support my local community.  This kind of restaurant is one of the reasons it's great to live in San Francisco and not  be surrounded by national chains.  Osteria is special.
author: wendy b.

description: What a great restaurant!  From the moment I walked in and smelled the aroma of good Italian food I knew it was going to be good.  And it was!  I had the insalata Della casa which was very simple but delicious.  Then the Gnocchi which was the best I ever tasted, melted in my mouth.  The wait staff was very polite and attentive.  Great meal!
author: Carol M.

description: We've been coming to osteria for years.  This is my favorite Italian in the city.  The tortalini proscuto is my all time favorite.    Strong recommend you try this nice local establishment.
author: Dan Q.

description:
Osteria is the prototypical Italian neighborhood restaurant that also doubles as that special occasion romantic date night choice.  In fact, we tell the kids this would be a good place for a first date.  You can even walk across the street to catch a nice movie after dinner at the neighborhood theater for your dinner and a movie date.

We made reservations for an early dinner for 4 for my gal's birthday.  We were greeted by Gina, the proprietor.  We were seated promptly and asked if we were on any time budget.  We started with the shrimp artichoke appetizer as well as the pancetta with brussels sprouts.  The brussels sprouts appetizer I've had a couple times here and love itt

On this occasion I had the mushroom risotto special instead of my normal  gnocchi. My dining companions had the tagliarini and the tortellini.  We ate it all and then finished with the hazelnut flan and tiramisu  for dessert.  They even added the candle and sang!

The dishes are standard Italian dishes or slight twists and done in a very unpretentious way but with some sophistication.  One could quite possibly go to Osteria several times a week for a nice home cooked meal.

Early seatings have more young families and later seatings seem to cater to more adult families. Dinner was done in an hour and 20 minutes for those planning on a movie night.  We will be back as always.
author: Erik H.

description: We had a great server but very bad food. Bland food. Very bland. Carbonara heavy on the cream side with little pancetta. There is no cream in Carbonara. Very bland veal. Caesar Salad that I'm not sure was made with anchovies it was so tasteless.   The bread was good. But I'm not sure it was worth $150.
author: J J.

description: We used to eat dinner every week at the Osteria , wonderful meals and wine ,then we moved to Italy, returned home to San Francisco after 17 years there and guess what? The Osteria is still here serving fabulous food, wonderful waiters (who all speak Italian) and the amazing family who owns and runs the restaurant. A wonderful place for dinner.
author: Julie G.

description: A perfect neighborhood restaurant. I had linguini with white clam sauce and it was just what I hoped. Terrific comfort food after a busy day. The service was friendly, personal and prompt.
author: Ian G.

description: I went into Osteria last week with a friend for dinner.  We didn't have a reservation, but the place was not very crowded so we didn't think we would have any issue getting a table.  When we told the hostess we didn't have a reservation, she became visibly irritated and told us we needed a reservation.  I pointed out that there appeared to be plenty of space, and she reluctantly seated us.  Our service was good, and the food was delicious - the gorgonzola gnocchi was my favorite.  The restaurant was still not full by the time we left, so I was confused about the hostess making a big deal and giving us attitude.  Aside from her, it would have been an excellent experience.
author: Nicholas N.

description: We came here for a lunch, ordered a salad appetizer which was very great. The bread came with the salad was the greatest of all. We also ordered italian sausage pizza with mushroom ( succiccia as I remembered). Pizza was goog but we did not love the sausage with pizza taste. The waiter seemed cheery to the former customers and to us at first. When he learnt we were from Turkey he seemed a little changed. He did not do anything mean but became not cheery at all.
author: Aygül K.

description:
Last night I had one of the worst nights of my life after dining in this restaurant. It was 5:45 and I was headed in for an early dinner. When I walked in just before 6 the restaurant had one other couple sitting in it. A woman with long black hair asked if I had a reservation and I said no. She told us that the empty restaurant was fully booked for the night. My friend then let her know he had put in an open table reservation. Btw, open table had availability every half hour thru 9:30. They were not even close to fully booked. As the night went on we ordered food and had a lovely experience with our amazing waiter, Juan. We brought in two very nice bottles of wine and had them opened for us. In the middle of eating and just after opening our wine the same lady came over to our table gave us the bill and told us we had to leave bc a new reservation needed our table. I told her we too had a reservation so we were going to finish our meal, drink the wine, and then go. She told us we had to at least move to a different table bc even though we had a reservation it was booked by opentable and there is a time limit on how long you can stay with opentable reservations. That is not true. You can call opentable, we already did. We moved to the other table per her demand so we could at least eat our dinner and have our wine. As we moved seats we told her that in all of the years of living here we had never been treated so poorly in a restaurant. She then told us we could leave if we wanted to. I started to finish my food as quickly as possible as I just wanted to leave. She then returned to our new table to tell us how rude we were and that she'd comp our bill and to get out. I asked her to please leave our table as we finish up as quickly as possible. This is where the most horrific part comes in. As I'm eating my food, I see the restaurant being surrounding by 5 police cars. They rush into the restaurant and remove us. I have never gotten in any trouble in my life and we had done absolutely nothing wrong so needless to say I was scared and humiliated. I was immediately in tears so once the police took us outside they told us not to worry. They said they could tell we were good people but she demanded that we leave. They said  to just look at it as a free meal and to go enjoy the rest of the night. They were so kind to me and apologetic that helped with the initial trauma and fear of being bombarded by a barrage of police officers. 

It's fair to say that it was one of the scariest nights of my life. I cannot understand why the woman did not want us there since we walked in or why were treated so abusively. I hope that this review is helpful and that this never happens to anyone else. :(
author: Lauren P.

description: The good service, great food, and prices are surprisingly reasonable for the area.  It looks like everyone there is a regular patron.  A great comfortable neighborhood gem.   Hope it does not change.  It is very likely that we will return.  Do make reservations.
author: Emilia G.

description:
Old timer place in a cute neighborhood.

enjoy a glass of wine with classic antipasto, entrees, and desserts.  we had the grilled veges which was simple.  then we split the special of the day, penne with meatball and the veal with lemon caper sauce.  pasta was decent, topped with shaved parm.  veal was tender and light.  for dessert, we shared the classic tiramisu, which was light, fluffy and delicious.

service was friendly.  full of locals in the neighborhood.  wine selection was good.
author: Linda T.

description: This is such a cute and delicious Italian restaurant! Has such a nice home feel to it and the food is excellent!! Great service as well!
author: Ashley G.

description:
I ordered the eggplant parm. and wanted pasta instead of the vegetable that came with it.  The waiter told me that no substitutions were allowed, but could order a half portion of pasta for an additional charge.  Eggplant parm  comes with a side of pasta in all the Italian restaurants I've dined, and was disappointed that it was not included here.  Pasta is a very low food cost item and frankly surprised that it was not offered with the main course,
The eggplant parm. was delicious as was the sauce.  It was not greasy and either lightly breaded or no breading at all.  
My wife ordered the pasta with sauce and enjoyed her meal.
We finished two bread baskets.  The bread was nice and fresh and had a good flavor.
I would have given 5 stars if substitutions were allowed.
I would just like to know their reasoning behind the no substitution rule.
author: Jerry J.

description:
Osteria is our favorite go-to Italian restaurant when we want to treat ourselves to a nice white tablecloth dinner.  Gina and her staff are very warm and with a nice, intimate upscale neighborhood environment away from the crush of Fillmore Street in Pac Heights.  We see lots of regulars every time we visit with an array of (well behaved) families dinning on occasion. 

Their food offerings are very good and consistent and they usually have one or two specials each night that are occasionally worth trying.  My wife favorites are the Insalata Di Spinaci,Tagliarini Contadina and Scaloppine or Piccata Di Vitello.
author: Brent V.

description:
Pretty solid neighborhood Italian restaurant with good quality food. 

We came here for Valentine's dinner and surprisingly the restaurant was not too crowded, but there were definitely couples coming in throughout the night, likely with reservations. The ambience is actually relatively bright with light colored walls.

Foodwise, everything was tasty and portions were generally decent. We ordered mussels, a blood orange fennel salad, and gnocchi pomodoro to share, and veal piccata and pork over polenta for entrees. I will say that the veal piccata was more of a traditional Italian second course size while the pork special had a lot more food. 

Service was fairly attentive and friendly. 

This place is worth checking out if you live in the area.
author: J L.

description:
This restaurant is owned/ managed by the cutest old man. I made a reservation for 2 at 8:45 and when my friend and I walked him he jumped up from his little nook in the corner and knew immediately who we were (I don't think it was necessary to make a reservation. He was so adorable and at the end when we left, he got up from his dinner to personally thank us for coming in. 

The atmosphere was very cute and family oriented. 

Food- We ordered the caprese appetizer and the spinach pasta with shrimp. The caprese was good and came with a pesto sauce which I really liked. The spinach pasta with shrimp was really good. They were little baby shrimps which were interesting but the actual pasta was delicious and the cream sauce was light but flavorful.

As for the bread we got at the beginning, I wish there would have been a better sauce, like an olive oil- garlic- spices sauce, instead of just plain olive oil.

All in all, it was a very cute little place and I would be down to come again.
author: Jenna G.

description:
I came here to see one of their Monday night acoustic performances. It's a tiny place, full of Botoxed SF yuppie matrons and other pretentious liberal types, but the atmo is fairly cozy and homey. On Mondays, they squeeze the performers in the front of the room, by the windows facing the street...so if you want to see the act, better request a table up front. The place is small enough so you can hear the music from any table, but the view is best from up front.

Food-wise, I had 2 glasses of wine, a spinach salad and some risotto ($55 total). All were good, but nothing exceptional. 

Service was attentive and polite...everyone was friendly, and I felt pretty comfortable, despite the fact I was sort of underdressed (upscale-casual seems to be the shtick here).

Without the live music, the ambiance would probably be kinda weird...so not sure I'd come here again, unless some I knew or liked was performing.
author: Sarah Jane W.

description: After going to the movies at the Vogue movie theater we went into the restaurant across the street, Osteria without a reservation. We were a party of 9  & were accommodated by the pretty, gracious hostess who seated us immediately. She asked us if we had reservations. The Decor  had an Italian feel. I must say the food was the best part of our night. Almost 3 hours  into it we did not feel rushed and we had a wonderful meal that felt as if it was cooked by grandma... after talking to the of hostess we discovered it had been around for over 20 years and we now know why...Thank you for a wonderful Italian dinner - now it's a regular eating place for me and I am on my 4th visit.  Ran into Madeleine Albright on my third visit
author: Milly M.

description: Came here with two other "young" people. The bread and olive oil were good, the wine and pasta I really don't remember so they must not have been that great. After paying the bill I asked, who I presumed, was the Executive Chef, where the bathrooms were. He pointed to the street and with a straight face and bite in his voice said I had to go outside. Disgusting way to treat a paying customer, especially on a slow night.
author: Kali C.

description:
We had fine dinner here after a show nearby. The place was nearly full, but they got a cancellation via open table and were able to take us on short notice.

Excellent gnocchi, and delicious tender calamari steak. Attentive friendly service. Better meals than I've had for twice the price.
author: David L.

description:
Hey Mambo, Mambo Italiano!
Hey Mambo, Mambo Italiano!
Go, go, Joe, you mixed up Sigiliano!
All you Calabrese do the mambo like crazy...

I rarely make it over to Laurel Heights for no particular reason except I have no reason to go there. Except on Wednesday when Jamie W. and I happened to be in the neighborhood to see none of the city mayoral candidates duke it out in a debate at the spacious Jewish Community Center. It went on so long that we just had to skedaddle to satisfy our stomachs before fainting from another argument about pension reform. We just strolled up Presidio a block and happened upon Osteria. Glad we did. 

Hey Mambo! Don't wanna tarantella,
Hey Mambo! No more-a moozzarella.
Hey Mambo! Hey Mambo Italiano.
Try an enchilada with a fish-a-barcalada.

This is what I call a real neighborhood Italian place. You could tell the gregarious owner Vahid Ghorbani takes great pride in his place by the way he greets you and explains all his daily specials in great detail. The menu is traditional Northern Italian - no heavy red sauces but plenty of seafood and cream sauces. Jamie and I shared the $8 Pomodoro Affetatto con Gamberetti, basically a shrimp salad in a light Green Goddess-like dressing scooped on top of a sliced tomato and a heart of palm with red pepper strips (see photo). A bit fussy in a grandma sort of way but good. 

Hey goombah!
I love-a how you dance rumba.
But take-a some advice paisano,
learn how to mambo.
If you're gonna be a square,
you're never gonna go nowhere.

We both went for pasta for our entrees. Jamie ordered the $14 Tortellini Della Casa, which came in a hearty meat sauce (see photo), while I opted for the $15 Tagliarini Contadina, which came with chicken, chunks of tomato, and sliced shiitake mushrooms. Only they were out of tagliarini and served linguine instead, as if I would have noticed a difference (see photo). Both were good, old-fashioned plates of carb goodness with plenty enough going on to be quite satisfying on a crisp night in Laurel Heights. 

Hey Mambo, Mambo Italiano!
Hey Mambo, hey Mambo Italiano!
Go, go, Joe, shake-a like a Gioviano.
Hello quesadicha,
you getta happy in the feets-a

Valid lured us with his $8 Tiramisu, which was uncommonly well made with a hint of Kahlua in the highly calorific blend of ladyfingers, espresso and marscarpone cheese (see photo). Quite delicious, and we were not worthy to deserve such a treat. Jamie and I both agreed that we'd give Osteria another try if we were in the neighborhood, but like I said, we're never in that neighborhood. But maybe, just maybe, we won't get off at Polk when we're on the 1 California and let ourselves indulge in some of that tiramisu again. 

Hey Mambo, Mambo Italiano!
Hey Mambo, Mambo Italiano!
Go, go, Joe, you mixed up Sigiliano.
It's-a so delish-a, everybody gonna preshi-ada.
Mambo Italiano!

FOOD - 4 stars...good, old-fashioned Northern Italian dishes 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...a nice and airy spot good enough for grandma and Gen-Y'er alike 
SERVICE - 4 stars...Vahid was a charmer 
TOTAL - 4 stars...killer tiramisu may just warrant a repeat visit
author: Ed U.

description:
Kinda your average Italian neighborhood restaurant. 

I've never been blown away by a meal here, but the food is decent. I enjoy their carpaccio and antipasto assortito (mmm hearts of palm), and as for entrees, I've always gone with pasta and they're always fairly tasty -- just not in any way memorable or extraordinary.

For some reason I've been here several times, mainly because business associates work nearby. I think it's just a pity when San Francisco has so many phenomenal Italian restaurants (Beretta, Flour + Water, Delfina and so many more I haven't even had the chance to try yet) ... you catch my drift.

On the positive side, the vibe is very family-friendly -- you won't have to worry about taking Mom or Grandma to Osteria because she will be surrounded by her peers.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Osteria seemed like a neighborhood restaurant in a very nice neighborhood.  Down the street from two of my favorites - Spruce and Sociale - it had a lot to live up to and most certainly did.   The linguine alla vongole tasted the same as it did in Venice with one interesting exception - they substituted basil for italian parsley, which totally worked.  The winner, though, was the spinach gnocchi my wife ordered.  It raced to the top of her all-time favorite gnocchis; beating out the salmon one we had in Croatia!  The wines by the glass were both excellent.  For dessert we had the cheesecake with lemon - fantastic.    This pace is definately worth a visit.
author: Marcus P.

description: Authentic and fresh! The staff treat you like family! Who could ask for more! The pear salad was a treat and the homemade cheese cake is light and delicious.
author: Chris C.

description: Good Italian food but nothing to write home about. The space is very nice and cozy as others have described and the staff is extremely friendly and accommodating. The price is very reasonable compared to other Italian restaurants in the area.
author: Marcus P.

description: Ate a delicious dinner here with my mom and absolutely loved the gnocchi pomodoro that I got! The service was wonderful, just make sure to have a reservation in case it is a busy night! Both plates were cleared and bread was devoured. They serve both beer and wine, and a nice variety of both, though there are no cocktails. It is a lovely layout on the corner with lots of windows to help with the people watching. Great place to eat!
author: Rachel S.

description:
The food here is absolutely terrific. One of my good friends suggested this for my birthday dinner so we made reservations for a Friday night, showed up on time and were seated. Everything was fine except for the service. 

The food was absolutely delicious and I love the environment of the restaurant. It was very comfortable and cozy. However, service is really important to me and the waitress we had seemed really grumpy and damped our mood a bit. 

I don't know if I'll be back again. The food, again, was really great but the service turned me off to the restaurant. We'll see.
author: Jeannie M.

description:
Its just ok.  It has the cuteness neighborhood thing going on, and the lovely host and waiters - but the food is just ok.  
We had risotto ( a bit over cooked and over flavored ) and the linguine w clams and a few salads.  
Food needs a step up - thats all I am saying.  Go local, go fresh.
author: Lione B.

description: Food was simply not good....Our server was pretty nice though (thus the 2 stars, rather than 1).  There are much better Italian restaurants in town.
author: Charlie D.

description: Went to dinner with a girlfriend last night.  Friendly service.  Delicious olive oil as the starter.  The salmon was good,and the menu said sustainable.  I forgot to ask if this was wild caught or farmed raise.  It would be helpful if they indicated.  These days I'm only eating fish in the city caught by Two by Sea.  But overall, great meal.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I really enjoyed this restaurant. I have been back a few times and try to go when I am visiting SF.

The staff is always very friendly. This place is small and quaint which is nice when your in San Francisco. Its a neighborhood restaurant. 

They have some good wine choices that aren't super expensive. Which is also sometimes hard to find these days. 

Really have enjoyed eating here and will be visiting again sometime soon.
author: G L.

description:
We have been dining at Osteria for a number of years.  Over the past couple of years it has been at least once a month.

Many other restaurants we've enjoyed over the years have closed and/or their food and service
deteriorated to the point where we stopped going.  Also, a number of restaurants have raised
their prices to the point where we will go only for special occasions.

Osteria has actually improved over time.  They have a diverse Italian menu, ingredients are always fresh, food is very well prepared, service is excellent, and their portions are very generous.  On many occasions we will order one or two starters and split the main course
and walk out comfortably full.  Prices are very reasonable for the quality of the food,  the portions, and the excellent service.

I like to order a glass of wine with my meal.  Their wines go well with the food and the pours are
very generous.

We went there for dinner on New Year's Eve with two other couples who were not familiar with
the restaurant.  Everyone was very happy with the meal and the service was excellent.  They
were very busy that evening but we were seated right on time and servers did not miss a beat.

They had a special menu for New Year's and the price was appropriate for the occasion.  We
actually wound up paying a little more than we would pay on a regular evening at most of the
restaurants where we dine.  Our friends were very pleased and Osteria will probably be where
we dine December 31, 2016.

P.S.  Yelp sometimes takes posts out because they think they come from people connected to
a place.  You can check with Open Table to see how often we dine there and many times I will
go there on my own without making a reservation when I've had a long day and my wife is
elsewhere.
author: michael s.

description: Ordered the gnocchi, chicken parm and salmon. All were delicious and very well prepared. Service is exceptional- very helpful and friendly. A nice neighborhood spot it you live in the area but also worth traveling to.
author: Hadley B.

description: One of our favorites the last 24 years.  A neighborhood restaurant that never disappoints.  Every time we are in the city my wife and I go to Osteria for a fantastic meal.  Our favorite waiter retired but service is still fantastic!  My wife and I always have the same.  Veal Picatta for me and Gnocchi for her.  Their salad dressing is fantastic and was published online for a while.
author: Jose G.

description: Stopped by early this evening without a reservation was shown to a table and treated like royalty. Thanks to Juan, et al   for dining recommendations and excellent service. .  I've dined at Osteria a half-dozen times over the years and have found it  a lovely respite from a stress-filled day.  No television, and no Muzak. GREAT !
author: Claudia S.

description:
We wanted very much to like Osteria, as its location is so convenient for us.  The reviews were quite mixed, but we decided to take a slot on OpenTable and give it a try on a recent Friday evening.

When we arrived a few minutes before our reservation, the person who greeted us seemed surprised that we had a reservation, and told us we would have to wait. She blamed OpenTable for making a reservation they weren't ready to accept.  All restaurants can run behind, and waiting for a table on a busy evening is fine. What bothered us was the overall sense of annoyance that the staff displayed towards us and our reservation, far from the welcoming attitude we have come to expect in neighborhood restaurants.

When we were finally seated, we were given a single menu for our party of 3, and were told they were dealing with a menu shortage. Fine, except that the larger party seated a few minutes after us had menus given to each guest, including several children. Despite the fact that we waited about 12 minutes for someone to take our order, we were not given another menu.

The food was fine but inconsistent.  The brussels sprouts appetizer was very well-done and tasty, with pleasing flavors and just the right done-ness.  My Chicken Marsala, one of the specials that night, was overdone and quite dry.  The sauce and accompanying vegetables were quite good.

The service could most generously be described as benign neglect.  No check-ins once we had ordered, no sign that our server was aware of how very long we were waiting for our meal.  Once our dishes were delivered, it was difficult to even get our water glasses filled.  By the time we were done, we just wanted to get the check and leave, but it took some time to even catch someone's eye to accomplish that.  Is it possible that this place was simply overtaxed on a busy Friday evening, and that we would have a better experience at another time?  I suppose so, but I do not plan to return to find out.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description: This is a busy little restaurant. I suggest reservations or eat later in the evening. Service was very good as was the food. Good selections and will please everyone in your dinner party. Locals were eating here which I feels is a good sign!
author: Kim B.

description:
My boyfriend and I checked out this place on Friday. I had a gone a few years ago and had a great experience, but unfortunately that was not the case on Friday. We had a 7:30 reservation and were seated immediately, which was great, but the experience went downhill from there.

We ordered a bottle of wine while we were perusing the menu (the Zin, which was a decent bottle for under $50) and while the waitress was pouring the wine I ordered an appetizer, the antipasto for two, and asked her a few questions on the menu. By the time she was done pouring, we were ready to order and did so. I went with the angel hair pasta with fresh tomato sauce, garlic and basil, and added prawns and my boyfriend got the spinach pasta with chicken, tomatoes and shiitake mushrooms. (Both were good, mine was better.)

Less than a half of glass of wine later (so, I'd say less that 5 minutes), our pasta comes out to the table. No sign of an appetizer in sight. My boyfriend asked the waitress and she said oh, I am sorry, do you want me to put your food under a heat lamp and get you your appetizer? Of course we didn't want our pasta sitting around, so we declined, but were very disappointed. And while she did offer us free dessert about 5 minutes later, she didn't seem to really care that she had made a mistake. (We all make mistakes, but own up to it, right?) Also, the pasta came out so fast that we had no time to just enjoy the wine - the whole experience felt rushed. After we started eating I saw that other tables were being offered fresh Parmesan to go on their dishes - so I asked her to bring some over, and when we received the dessert we ordered, it was not presented as nicely as the other items we saw come out. I know, some little things, but if you mess up, which is human, at least try to make up for it!

So to recap, the food and wine, pretty good, the service? Needs improvement.
author: Jane F.

description:
Plus: the food was excellent, and not over priced for its class and type.

That said.
I made a reservation with Open Table for tonight, a Monday, when it opened, at 5:00. Easy. My mom and I got there, and were the only people there. It took two minutes to get acknowledged. Despite every table being open and having a reservation, the waiter told us to come back. We shopped for a minute and came back, and were reluctantly seated. We considered just walking out, but decided to give it a try anyway.

Still, we were literally the only two people in the restaurant. It nevertheless took minutes, the two employees were much too busy arranging seats for other parties who were not yet there. We made our order, and after the food arrived, we were not paid attention to at all for the rest of the meal. Other parties were arriving, along with a band. The waiter, a 40-something hipster who still went by Andy, had the same snooty attitude with all the other customers as well.

The terribly poor service, along with the generic, soulless atmosphere, made for an experience I'd not want to repeat. It made for an excellent opportunity to tell my mom all about the huge amount of entitlement amongst a huge percentage of San Franciscans, and how this type of BS is just so common these days. What ever happened to just being a nice person?
author: Alex L.

description:
Very mixed experience.  Four of us went to hear a singer who was there this Monday night.   We had never been there before.  The first problem was the set up - this place should never book entertainment.  Only the front two tables out of the 10 or 12 in the restaurant can actually see and hear the entertainment, a disservice to the artists and the diners. 

Service was very slow due to understaffing.  There was one waiter and one busboy for the entire place.  The waiter had essentially given up trying to keep up; you would just have to wait.  It took 30 minutes from seating to ordering and another 25 minutes to get our appetizer and drinks and another 30 min. to get dinner, so I assume the kitchen was backed up too.

The food was adequate; of the four dishes we ordered, one was meh, two were ok and one was very good. The appetizers were ok...nothing special, but ok.  

May we hit a bad night.  The fact that one dish was very good indicates tht the kitchen can turn our outstandning food, but if they are rushed and backed up, don't expect it.  I won't go back, but others may be luckier than we were.
author: Patrick O.

description:
I've lived in the neighborhood for years and passed by Osteria countless times. I've always wanted to try it but somehow never made it over there. That all changed last weekend. My boyfriend and I were on a loooong walk through the Presidio, to the Marina and back and decided to finally venture in when the warm glow from the bustling restaurant lured us out of the rain. We didn't have a res (obviously) but Gina greeted us warmly and told us we could wait for a table. She anticipated 45 mins. We decided to head over to Swank for a cocktail to "kill the time". That was fun! (See separate review for Swank). Then we headed back over to Osteria and Gina had our table ready for us! 

We were immediately given some lovely bread and offered still or sparkling water. The menu looked awesome. We were hard pressed to pick just one starter and one entree but we managed. I started with the insalata della casa - a butter lettuce salad with delicious green goddess dressing. Dave opted for the Caesar - I stole a crouton and it was gooood. 

We ordered a bottle of wine that Gina recommended to us and it paired perfectly with everything we ordered. I'm completely forgetting what it was - but for $42 it was a steal. Gina orders all of the wine for the restaurant so she is well acquainted with the wine list and can help you with any questions you may have.

For our entrees I ordered the linguine with clams in a light white wine sauce (amazing) and my bf ordered the tortellini with peas in a cream sauce. Both dishes were cooked to perfection. We seriously ate every last bite and almost licked our plates. Luckily decorum won out over gluttony. Phew.

Gina introduced us to their fantastic-looking dessert menu and while the cheesecake sounded out of this world, we just didn't think we'd have room after gorging on everything else. Gina comped one for us since it was our first visit and told us to enjoy ourselves. We did!!!

Food: totally authentic, cooked perfectly and downright delish.
Service: awesome! Gina, the owner/food server/wine connoisseur made our experience wonderful.
Ambiance: great! Even with it being a full house it never got so noisy that we couldn't talk.

Totally recommend and can't wait to return :)
author: Carrie S.

description:
Two years ago we met some mutual friends for a dinner here. We hadn't had much contact since our children were elementary school aged long ago. The great food, atmosphere, and great wine had us laughing  like long lost friends. Great wine, good veal, and a stellar antipasto. 

I'm in my 50's now and the comments about old people, hearing devices, blue hair makes me chuckle.  This sounds like insecurity from a generation that can't seem to do anything without a phone in their hand, checking it during a nice dinner with friends, and generally clueless about how to behave socially. The ball cap wearing crowd indoors is a real peeve. (There's a great scene in the Sopranos when Tony confronts a 20 something doing the same)


Great food Osteria. We will be back soon.
author: Michael S.

description: Outstanding food and service.  Cozy, warm ambience.  Always a great dining experience.
author: Molly C.

description: Great food! Reasonably priced & great service. A nice treat. I recommend the Risotto of the day!
author: Sarah M.

description: Great service! Very authentic! I would recommend it to anybody passing through or for a solid night of good Italian food!
author: Taylor J.

description:
Before I tell you why I rated Osteria so low, I need to give you some context of the evening. We were starving and hadn't eaten since before noon, and it was after 8p by now. We were going to make something at home but decided it was too late and we were too hungry to put in the effort, so I called Osteria. I ordered the grilled chicken (petto di pollo paillard alla griglia, as it's listed on the menu), and my girlfriend ordered the gnocchi. 

When I got home, the two meals were packaged nicely and were still hot. As we started eating, I noticed that the portions were good sized, the chicken was filleted completely and looked very big. The food seemed to be prepared well. I was pretty happy until my 5th or 6th bite, when I bit into a combination of chicken and vegetables and felt and heard something unusual as I pulled the bite from my fork. As I started to chew I realized there was a long hair that was intertwined in my chicken. To make it worse, the unusual sound I heard was the hair breaking numerous times. I removed the food from my mouth and began to inspect the chicken. I found 3 long hairs that had found their way into the fillet of the chicken. 

This isn't the first time I found a hair in my food. Hair is natural and not unheard of in food preparation. I have even finished a couple of meals that had hair on the edge of a plate or even found laying on a portion of food. 

But this time was different for me. In the context that Osteria is a "nicer" restaurant, and the price of the food was not that of a diner, I expect more. In addition the hair was intertwined in the chicken prior to cooking and was not simply on the edge or even on top of food. Unfortunately, I lost my appetite, and so did my girlfriend, and chose to not finish the meals. 

I understand that this was most likely an isolated incident, but I will not return to Osteria.
author: Jeremie B.

description: I hadn't been to this place in a long time, gave it a try with my dad the other day and again about a week later with a friend. Awesome. Food is simply delicious without being heavy. A lot of Italian places are too heavy on the pasta, not here. Fresh fresh ingredients, superbly put together. Service is refined and top notch without being stuffy or pretentious. Prices are a little more than a regular night out, but worth every penny. I would come back here any day if invited.
author: Matt A.

description:
I recently dined with a friend in SF. Since she's pregno I let her pick the restaurant...and we ended up here at Osteria. And Italian food is always A-OK by me.

I was leaning towards the calamari steak entree, but when the waiter informed me it was fried I opted for the chicken scallopini instead.  The chicken was scrumptious and I had no problems cleaning my plate...even after eating way too many pieces of their yummy bread.

My friend's pasta dish looked delish as well. The service was also good & fast...and fast service seems to be a rarity in California.
author: Andrea R.

description:
Osteria serves up some tasty dishes worth coming back for and the decor isn't tacky like other Italian restaurants. We tried the gnocchi, carpaccio, bruchetta and tiramisu. The bruchetta was a bit different with marinated shaved fennel root. 

We came for acoustic Mondays to see a friend play. The performers were very good. I'm not usually into live music so this is a huge deal for me. The music was a bit loud for my old lady ears and it was hard to chat so we mostly sat in silence or tried to scream across the table.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
neighborhood dining room: warm, bright, cheery and clean atmosphere redolent with beaming waiters, opera singing expediter, seasoned cooks, and delicious food. extremely professional delivery of service, even if the offerings are not on par with san francisco's farm to table/local/sustainable/seasonal food scene. 
This is a great place to take laid back, easy to please friends and family who you just want to enjoy a fulfilling, quality, stressless, and fun weekday night meal with. smiles vacated the spaces of all faces this evening at this fantastic little italian-american eatery. 
very good chilled rueda spanish white wine. fresh from the chilled bottled. yum! a must try if you're in the neighborhood and in need of a classic italian 3 course meal. the caesar salad and the spinach/mushroom salad are both 5 star!
author: Libra J.

description:
The pasta,  Caesar salad, Italian wine and bread were delicious and reasonably priced and the service was most gracious and fast, as we asked for a quick meal before going to a movie across the street at Vogue. The place was packed and had a congenial feeling. This is the kind of neighborhood gem that clearly has a loyal following. Atmospheric. Able to talk  without yelling.  We are returning
~ Kare  & Walt
author: Kare A.

description:
I find Osteria a bit less pretentious when compared to Garibaldi's (across the street), but alas, San Francisco still does not manage to deliver top notch italian cuisine. The restaurant bathes in beautiful rays of afternoon sun giving it a sort of  golden glow; it's actually quite gorgeous! The atmosphere itself is very calm and serene but is sadly ruined by waitstaff running around like headless chickens. I mean honestly, there wasn't that much business when I was seated but the waiters and waitresses were coming in and out, back and forth, and it didn't look like they were doing much.

When I was ready to order, I decided on the house gnocchi as the dough was made fresh in the kitchen and munched on my house bread. Not much to say on the bread; the olive oil was olive-y; maybe they could have added some additional spices like red pepper or parmesan cheese? Either way I was not impressed.

When my Gnocchi arrived I was disappointed first in the portion size. When spending $20+ a plate I expect a little bit bigger of a portion rather than just a kids size meal. I finished my gnocchi in about 2 minutes with the intention of making the meal last longer. In a traditional sense, I suppose I should have ordered a main course along with my pasta but even still, the gnocchi was just alright. 

My red wine was great and paired well with the pasta however the gnocchi was quite bland. I ordered tiramisu for dessert and found that tasty and authentic. I probably wouldn't come out of my way for Osteria but I did notice they do take out, which is convenient, if you're looking for a quick decent italian fix.
author: Tommy C.

description:
Average italian food - I tried:
1) minestrone soup (lots of vegetables, a bit too much black pepper, and not enough beans)
2) gnocchi with tomato sauce (nice, but a bit eggy tasting; the sauce could have done with more basil)
Friendly staff, quick service, family friendly.  Well-priced, and good portion sizes (not too big/small). 
I'd go back at some point.
author: Shweta V.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised the food was great I had the calamari it was so tender . My friend had the scampi it was to die for . The salad was good as well as the desert
We ordered takeout for someone else gnocchi Gorgonzola perfect. 
Service was fine . Greatbplace
author: Stef M.

description:
Pretty good: very flavorful risotto that was just a tad soft in texture, and excellent Italian lemon cheesecake (lighter than traditional NY cheesecake). The service started out quite good & friendly but over time they forgot about me.

Very nice cozy atmosphere, in a small, quiet commercial district.
author: George F.

description: Great neighbohood destination with a steady, reliable menu. They also have live music on Monday nights--be sure to reserve a table ahead of time for that!
author: Dan B.

description:
I don't know why so many are ripping this place.  It's good home style food. Their tomato sauce isn't diluted like Bella, nor are they fancy like Seven Hills.  If you actually do the research on the name "Osteria" the definition comes up "A place serving wine and simple food."

So yes I'm very much a fan of this place.  The food is simple, as their name should suggest, it's got an old style Italian American restaurant feel to it like most Italian restaurants in Chicago and Long Island.

I'm going back and the food was good.  The Spaghetti and Meatballs was good, and their Tiramisu was the way I like it: A bunch of cocoa powder and Kahlua added in.

Service was good and the head of the front house actually got pissed off when another waiter told us the cheesecake was ricotta instead of cream cheese.  After mentioning it to the waiter she came to us told us of his error and we ordered it anyway.

Simple, honest food.
author: Adrian E.

description:
If you gave this place a 5, you're an idiot.
If you gave this place a 4, you're an idiot.
If you gave this place a 3, you're an idiot.

Yelp has been an awesome sidekick, but sometimes I have to scratch my head and wonder how many idiots are on here pretentiously writing like they actually know about food.  Look at this guy saying "a shrimp salad in a light Green Goddess-like dressing scooped on top of a sliced tomato..."  Dude WAKE UP!  It was a spoonful of precooked, preprocessed store bought small shrimp on a slice of butter lettuce and a slice roma tomato!!  Did you seriously enjoy it that much?  You couldn't thrash that together from the safeway dumpster?

My belle and I came here for a Saturday night date and were very excited based on reviews by you idiots.  The place caters to the 60+ crowd; I know some of you other idiots said it was "lively," but realistically everyone's screaming since they're all hard of hearing.  Whatever, I've volunteered at elderly care places and I enjoy elderly people - but I wanted to clear up the atmosphere.

The bread was absolutely delicious with the olive oil - if they make the bread there, then I'm seriously perplexed by the quality of the rest of the dishes.

I ordered veal scallopini with lemon and caper sauce.  When it got to my table, I was absolutely disgusted.  The veal was grey, not browned (haven't you heard of a maillard reaction?!?).  The sauce - OMG THE SAUCE!!! It was covered in a greyish, slimy, flavorless WHITE ROUX based sauce with lemon juice and capers!!!!  I took a look around and saw that everyone's food had the same color and was absolutely disgusted.  I can just picture a big tub of roux in the back bubbling away all day.  Whenever they need to make a sauce, they'd mix a ladle full with whatever flavoring agents.  Seriously - the most expensive item on the menu and you cheated.  
Shame on you.  

Is it that hard to make veal scallopini without cheating?  Here's how (and PAY ATTENTION TO THE DAMN SAUCE):
Flour on veal (helps it brown) - throw it in an oil/butter mix - cook until done and remove from pan.
Skim fat, put in white wine, lemon juice, and capers and reduce for 2 minutes
Turn OFF the heat and whisk in a cold tablespoon of butter (Monte Beurre method)

THAT'S IT!!  IS IT THAT HARD!?!?

WHERE'S ROBERT IRVINE?!?!?!?@!?!?@#!?@
author: Nico M.

description: Every time I come here I wonder why I don't come in more! Wait no - I don't come here more because then I would be SO obese. I love italian food like no other and this place does homestyle italian just right. Solid portions for standard prices and great customer service! I once left a scarf there and called a month later and they had held onto it! They also sometimes have live music which is great!
author: Alexandra M.

description: We were really hoping that this would be our new favorite Italian spot. Instead I think we brought the average age down in that restaurant to about 70. The food was mediocre - heavily sauced overcooked pasta and not a very creative menu. We won't be going back.
author: Paty H.

description: Came here on a Tuesday night at 7:30pm for my mother's birthday dinner. We made reservations so we were seated immediately in a small little area on the side of the restaurant. They had fresh tulips for the tabletop design. We ordered an appetizer called ANTIPASTO ASSORTITO (FOR TWO) for $20 which has prosciutto, salami, tuna, heart of palm, artichoke and eggplant. I love prosciutto so I was pretty excited to eat this. I loved the artichoke most with its green sauce on top! We then had our own entree. I had the GNOCCHI FATTI IN CASA with meat sauce, my mom had the pasta of the day, and my sister had the TAGLIARINI CON GAMBERETTI. All three dishes were flavorful and we had leftovers because the appetizer was quite filling. We were also served bread with balsamic vinaigrette and oil. Delicious, but it filled us up before the main entree. The service was excellent, though their accent could make it hard for us to understand them sometimes, but they were super nice! Got our bill, to-go boxes, and everything served to us quickly. They also packaged our foods to-go for us. Very closeby home, so I will definitely be back again. I rate this place 4.5 stars for its good service, good food, and decent price for the quality!
author: Amanda C.

description: How anyone can give this place less than amazing reviews is beyond me.  I've eaten here a few times - with large groups or with only one other person.  The food is always delicious, and the staff are accommodating.  This past Sunday we showed up without a reservation, with 6 adults and 3 children - the owner's father was the host, and he was so nice to us.  He gave us a long table for the adults, and even allowed us to have a kids table - what restaurant in SF does that?!?!  It doesn't necessarily look like a kid friendly place, but it really is.  The pasta was delicious, and the kids even ordered seconds.  I believe that the previous owner passed away very suddenly a few years ago, and maybe some inconsistency ensued for a while while the family recovered from their loss and attempted to maintain the business.  IMHO, they've done an amazing job, and I'll be coming back here.
author: Cori D.

description: We ate here last night for the first time. The service was good and the pour of the wine was generous as were the potions. The food, however was lackluster and not worth the price. I had the gnocchi, which was actually too mushy. My husband's veal piccata was not good. The decaf cappuccino tasted like whatever solvent was used to extract the caffeine. We were really surprised at how well this place was reviewed on Yelp.
author: Rachele F.

description: Osteria is a solid restaurant in the neighborhood.  Not everything is fantastic, but there are some gems,  I really like their artichoke and shrimp appetizer, and their spinach pasta is good.  I wasn't impressed by their gnocchi, and several of their meat dishes have fallen flat for me.  They do have good bread, and I like their olive oil.  The servers are friendly, and it seems like a nice local place without any attitude.
author: Scott E.

description: Osteria Cucina Toscana serves simple, elegant, northern Italian fare in a cozy setting off the beaten track.  This unpretentious neighborhood gem, an increasingly rare find in San Francisco, offers tasty food, an impressive wine list and impeccable service.  Our server handled our large party with finesse and joked with our children.  The owner paid ample attention to her guests, some of whom were clearly on a first-name basis with her.  If you seek good food, good vibes and a good deal, this is the place for you.
author: Cat R.

description: Really good food, but terrible service. We arrived at 5:20 with no reservation. Two couples in the whole place. Then we waited. And waited. And waited. Waiter is looking right at us several times, finally comes over.  We get water, we get menus, and now we wait some more as the hostess stands and chats with a friend (her back to us) and the waiter ignoring us yet again, despite menus closed and to the side. I finally have to get up and interrupt the hostess' conversation so we can order. Waiter is training someone but doesn't sound thrilled about the specials. That's the last we see if him. Someone else brings food. Luckily, the food is good (the only good thing). Hard to enjoy, though, when several people insist on serving the table next to us with their butt practically resting on my place setting -- despite the table on the other side of this couple being empty. It was just all-around frustrating and we felt like we weren't up to their standards.
author: H C.

description:
I absolutely love this place!  We live in the East Bay, so it's a haul to get there for us but this is some of the best Italian food I have outside of Italy and better than much of what I have had in Italy.

I admit I am in a bit of a rut as I always order the same thing plus a different dish each time to share but I dream about their carpaccio which is to die for and the veal piccata which is so tender and the lemon in the sauce is just right.  My wife and I shared the lemon cheesecake and it was so creamy and just the right amount of lemon flavor.

Just a great neighborhood Italian restaurant that I go way out of my way to get to.
author: Dalr R.

description:
I have to admit I rarely write reviews on Yelp because usually the places I go to have a ton of reviews already. After my experience at Osteria I felt compelled to write one, because my dining experience was TERRIBLE! 

Service: Was fine nothing special

Price: I looked at the website to get an idea of the prices and it looked very responsible for the neighborhood. When we showed up the prices on the menu were all higher from the glasses of wine to the entrees...WTF who does that!

Food: Cheep ingredients, horrible presentation and bland bland bland! truly pathetic and shameful ESPECIALLY  because the entire restaurant is run by Italians!

I'm baffled by how this place is still in business and that it seems to be always busy. 

STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE!!!
author: joshua g.

description:
After walking by this place pretty much every day for the last few months I decided it was finally time to try it! I must say I was a little disappointed. No, it wasn't terrible at all, but it definitely wasn't worth the months of curiosity I allowed it. 

Those who say the place is "buzzing" are likely confusing the sounds of a hundred hearing aids for frenzy excitement. Definitely attracts an older crowd. Everyone there seems happy to be there though. 

Food was neither great nor terrible. I actually think the bread was the best part although I ordered the poached salmon and thought it was decent. Everything was a little over sauced - makes sense since the place is packed with deteriorating taste buds in need of accommodation. Not a bad place but not great either...
author: Zoey S.

description: I am sorry, of all the restaurants in SF I would save a dining trip and just order in if you are thinking of eating here. Or if you are too lazy to boil your own dried pasta and add canned sauce. But I think there are those that may need that service, therefore the extra star.
author: Kourtney P.

description:
We wandered in here before a comedy show.  The place was buzzing.  We didn't have a reservation.  The hostess told us that she would try to squeeze us in and we negotiated with her that we would be done by 7:30 since we had a show.  We did get a table!

The waiter was great and made it a memorable experience.  We shared a heart of palm salad with peppers.   The gnocchi was really really good.   

It is a sweet neighborhood spot and the people at the table next to us started talking to us.   It was all fun apart from the hostess who just didn't fit the atmosphere.   When we left we didn't understand why she made us feel like she was doing us a favor by giving us a table - there was no evening rush.  Oh well.  I will definitely be coming back here for the food, wine and great waiters.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
Just ok. It is a local spot that you go to if you are in your neighborhood. I got the spinach pasta with chicken and mushrooms. The pasta and sauce were good but it was really hard to find the chicken and mushrooms in this dish. Butter salad was over dressed. Wine list was awful. 

I think this is more of an older person place. We were visually the youngest people in the room. 55 and older is the crowd which is not a problem but was a strange coincidence. Felt like we hit an early bird special. 

Last but not least - I don't think anyone who works there is Italian or even Italian American. 

Ciao
author: Doreen D.

description:
This is a solid 3 1/2 star spot.  We live in the neighborhood and had never experienced Osteria and walked by a million times so decided we do a double date there. 

While I think our young age shocked the wait staff, the service was good, sometimes awkward but I chalked that up to them being shocked that a group under 55 was there for dinner on a Thursday night. 

I had the tortellini with meat sauce which was quite good, the Caesar salad was also tasty.  I wasn't a huge fan of the artichoke bottoms, i didn't like the sauce and thought there were too many shrimp plainly sitting on top of it.  Just not what I expected maybe? 

Like a said, a good 3 1/2 star spot.
author: Andrea R.

description: I'm really sad to read all these mediocre reviews...maybe you guys just aren't ordering the right stuff? The best pasta I've ever had is from here, and ok maybe I'm a little bias because it's the only thing I've ever ordered...but hey if it ain't broke, don't fix it! If you want a guaranteed delicisous meal, order the spinach pasta with shrimp. It's simple, with a light garlic butter sauce and fresh ingredients. The spinach pasta is house made and is always perfectly cooked to al-dente. The ceasar salad is super fresh and tangy too. I think the staff here is great- very personable and cheery and always happy to see you.
author: Kara L.

description: Solid Italian fare. Linguine alla vongole (red and white!) is great. Daily specials usually good. Only complaint is wine list is a bit sparse without having a couple of stand by classics. And no chianti (recent issue)?  Doh
author: John B.

description:
Trajesty after trajesty I finally had a good meal! 
(Trajesty = Travesty + tragedy) 

Came here with the whole family and it was a really good meal. Above average Italian can always cheer me up! The restaurant was able to seat our party of 16 right by the front window. A little cramped but it worked. Bread, water and oil were plentiful and of standard quality. I ordered the prosciutto and melon appetizer, tomato-basil gnocchi entre and tiramisu for dessert. I won't attempt to recall what everyone else got, but the bites I had were all good.

My only complaint of the meal was of the prosciutto to melon ratio. The prosciutto was excellent alone but was overwhelmed by the ammount of melon. Maybe that's how it's done in Italy, but in America I want more meat! 

The gnocchi was excellent! Perfect chewy, perfect tender and perfect portion size for me.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/-QCX1EAgUQBBrbddDkPK8g?select=_XPnqtkn51_YaRFP19pDng

Tiramisu was average, nothing wrong with it at all, but I've had better. 

Sadly, given the number of Italian restaurants in SF, I doubt I'll ever come here again by choice.
author: Eli G.

description:
food is okay. simple italian food, nothing exceptional.  would give them three stars, but the little cockroach on the wall staring at me brought it
down one star.
author: Girly Foodie F.

description: Fresh & flavorful pasta in a cozy neighborhood restaurant, but terrible and slow service for a large party of 14. Hostess was very unwilling to resolve our 14 person booking when the table was set for 12. Food came out extremely slow, given what seemed like a lack of kitchen staff and waiters. But very odd for some people to get their dishes when the rest of the table was finished eating. The best part was the eager Asian cheese grater man, he definitely lightened the mood for us!
author: Sheena Y.

description: If you are a young adult I recommend not coming to this place. While the food was good, the service was horrible. Not only were the staff rude and condescending towards us when we were ordering, but the manager managed to stop us when we were leaving and claim that we were 'dining and dashing.' The bill was on the table, and he said that it was "hiding." To the people of Osteria, just because you're young doesn't mean you don't have money.
author: G T.

description: Delicious food. I usually avoid marinara sauce, but I will be getting it next time I go (the bite I had of my friend's meal was delicious). The waitstaff was attentive and humorous. If we had not been at a table in the corner, the meal would have been very loud, but that's too be expected with such a small, busy restaurant. The meal was less expensive than I thought it would be considering the neighborhood. Over all it was a good experience and I'm sure I will be back.
author: Katie L.

description: I came here for the first time last night to see some friends play. (Every Monday is "Acoustic Bistro" that has 3 different singer/songwriters perform). Everything, from the wine, to the bruschetta (I usually hate tomatoes) to the calimari steak mungnaia to the gelato (a delicious combination of safron and pistachio) was mind blowingly delicious. The wait staff was wonderful (Minh is amazing), and I enjoyed the intimate setting. I would definitely go back!
author: Lindsay A.

description:
We met friends we haven't seen in over a decade. We had a big table near the window, enjoyed a great meal, and had some very good bottles of wine--I just told the server to pick what he thought best and he was spot on with a a white and several more Italian reds that matched up great.

 I'm not an expense account guy anymore, I teach school, but one thing I know is sometimes just let the place and the server simply 'take care of you" in old school Italian places and they never disappoint. Osteria is one of those places where I'd walk in and just say-Antipasto, soup, salad, and pasta- Bring us what you think is best as well as the wine that complements the food.

We just wanted to enjoy a good meal and re-connect with our friends instead of fretting and stressing over the food. Osteria did a great job. I felt like I was back in the dining room of my Italian American friends growing up in Stockton. The food was great, but the traditional SF/Italian menu made it easy to get something good to eat and allow us to focus on our fellowship, not worry if we ordered something goofy.

Antipasto-outstanding
Pasta w/Clams-just the right amount so I would feel like a bloated pig
Gnocchi- all who ordered it, loved it!
Salads-perfect and the dressings were all fresh

Parking is SF standard-a challenge sometimes but a good walk is a good thing in the neighborhood.
author: Michael S.

description:
This is a charming neighborhood restaurant with friendly staff and great food. I went twice in three days and enjoyed home made eggplant pram, veal piccata and a fabulous cheesecake. The wine was delicious too. 

For a single woman traveling alone, I was welcomed and completely comfortable.
author: Susan K.

description: This was a nice little cozy place. The lasagna was exceptional, the prices were reasonable, and you must try the lemon cheesecake. Moreover, I've been trying to explore the neighborhood (Laurel Haights) and this was a first nice experience.
author: Josué H.

description:
LOVE this restaurant!  Really enjoyed the wonderful food, excellent service, and unpretentious, friendly atmosphere!  My taglarini (pardon the spelling!) with bay shrimp, lemon and garlic was sublime.  My friend (who's birthday we were celebrating) enjoyed her linguini with clams just as much!  The icing on the cake -  so to speak - came when one of the very talented waiters came over and serenaded my friend with an Italian rendition of "Happy Birthday" in his fantastic operatic voice.  And speaking of dessert, tiramisu rocked as did the Gran Marnier custard.  What a feast!

The staff told us they will soon be opening up on Mondays featuring entertainment by Rome Bauer (wonderful singing waiter, who surely has a future on stage.)  Sounds like the Monday night menu with have a choice of small plates to be enjoyed with cocktails - sounds like a winning combination!  

I will certainly bring family and friends back to this neighborhood gem - it's a treat!!  Thank you to all who made us feel so welcome, and for the fabulous dinner!
author: Runr G.

description:
A gem of a little neighborhood Italian Restauran.

Ended up in the area and wanted a place to eat without driving around.  Glad we ended up here.  Very nice place.  May not win a Michelin star but tasty food, nice people, good atmosphere, and good service.  Actually liked the fact it was not a crowded tourist place.  Really enjoyed it.
author: L R.

description:
Maybe it was just a bad  experience, but it made me never want to return here again it was so bad. A group of friends and I ate here during a night with a set menu. 

Food wasn't great, portions were redonkulously small, and the prices were insane. If that weren't enough the server was a complete a-hole and further ruined the experience with a shitty attitude and arrogance.

Given, we were a group of guys in our early 20's so he may have been less than excited to serve us; however, little did he know how sophisticated a few of us were and we all live within a 10 block radius and how winning us over could've produced 4 more patrons that tip really well. Whoops!

If you are considering this place, I would say walk across the street and stroll into Garibaldi's, it's much better. Or Laurel/Sociale up the street a bit (Sacramento)  is really good too
author: Sam K.

description:
Ok, I'll admit it, I've never met a potato I didn't like, and will die to try gnocchi anywhere.  

This place was incredible, and the best gnocchi I've ever had.  Soft pillows of goodness, that actually tasted like potato, instead of starchy nuggets  (i had the tomato and basil sauce).  Really really good.

Also, we started with the assorted antipasto, which had three different types of cured meats, and heart of palm and artichoke hearts, all on a bed of bibb lettuce.  

The place had excellent cordial waitstaff.  

Reservation on a Saturday night is a must.  All in all, a cool place that I'd visit again.  Awesome for date night.
author: Beth V.

description:
We have considered Osteria a wonderful place to enjoy very good food--the gnocchi are the best ever; the wait staff is attentive and friendly; and the hostess is welcoming.  But we are put off by the host.  Would someone please tell him to get a decent haircut and comb his hair, wear clothes becoming to a white-table cloth restaurant not the worn blue jeans and tuck his shirt in at the waist and look like a professional.  His unkempt appearance lessens the pleasant atmosphere of this restaurant. 
Thank you.  I hope for improvement to this otherwise great neighborhood restaurant.
author: Deanna G.

description: Wonderful dining experience. Made reservations for large party and arrived with table ready.  Small restaurant with beautiful and understated Italian decor.  Some house wine and sourdough while waiting for orders and looked around and observed locals come in and pack the restaurant on this Tuesday night. Delightful!!  Food was delicious and pasta homemade. Loved the chicken Parmesan and the scampi.   Waiters were attentive and we met the owner.  The whole experience of food, gracious owner and local diners provided a wonderful evening for us. Loved it so much went back the next evening and same consistent experience.  Food was delicious but sometimes the dining experience is more than just the food. Try this place!
author: Jill M.

description:
I can't say enough good things about this charming neighborhood restaurant.

For our 30th wedding anniversary my wife and I decided to trip across the bay and spend the weekend in San Francisco, where we met.

We stayed in the Laurel Inn where they recommended Osteria for dinner. We ended up eating there twice.

Everything previous reviewers said about the gnocchi was correct. I couldn't decide which sauce I wanted so the waiter suggested half and half. Both were delicious. Like "butta".

The second evening I had calamari. It was the most tender calamari I have ever eaten. The sauce was perfect.

Service - Great, Atmosphere - Great, prices - reasonable.

I could go on for pages but I think your table is waiting. Enjoy
author: Sandy L.

description:
Crema Gianduia, yes, it's worth going just for this.  It gets better everytime I go.  I SO want the recipe.  Having it would not deter me from enjoying Osteria at all, I'd just be fatter from making this awesome desert at home.

The food on each visit has been consistently delicious.  This is one of my favorite spots in town for a dinner.  The staff are friendly and care about the quality they are serving.  The place is packed every time I go, so it's obvious others love this place as much as I do.

The only complaint I can offer is that the restaurant can become very noisy.  It's popular, tables are close and no carpeting means the noise level can get high enough to enable you not to hear some of your dinner companions.  Once the food arrives, the conversation can stop dead anyway.  The sign of a good meal, too busy eating to talk.

I've upped my review simply because after several experiences dining here, they're consistent with dishes I've tried before and even better with the new (to me) or seasonal dishes.
author: Donna H.

description:
Lots of people in the restaurant we were hoping the food was as good as it seemed! Unfortunately, the menu was much to be desired, the waitress was slow and non responsive to our requests, and the food was bland and boring. I was so disappointed!

We were warned not to get the artichoke shimp dish AND the shimp salad app because that would be "two shrimp dishes." What our waitress didn't tell us was that it was the EXACT same dish except one didnt have artichokes. The dish was even plated the same, no different sauces or anything. it was so bland and such a disappointment.

We then ordered the spinach salad. The vinagrette was non-existent and where it was on the plate it was TART. There was no substance to the salad. they put the dressing on the bottom and the dry leaves on top. Interesting, but not good.

I hope we just ordered the wrong thing, but then we also had the proscuitto,pea, tortillini dish. That wasn't good either! Missing flavor, too aldante, and the tortillini were similar to the ones u find int he grocery store under "Burtoli"

I was very unpleased with the meal. I was hoping to get out of there but no. Our check didnt arrive until 15 minutes after we requested it. It had already taken 10 minutes after we had finished eating for us to give up and ASK for the check ourselves.

Really horrible experience. Too bad because its in my neighborhood!
author: Kate M.

description:
Came here with my co-workers to have a gathering few times.  It looks like a neighborhood restaurant with simple setting and moderate decoration. 

My impression of this place seems to be a bit cramped.  When it is packed with people this place gets loud.  Even though the environment is not as comfortable as one think, the food is not bad at all.  

We usually order the carpaccio for appetizer, caesar salad, a pasta dish, a bottle of chardonnay for dinner.  As for dessert, they have good solid favorites.  However, the price is a bit high in my opinion, but overall this is a good, solid italian restaurant if you don't want to eat at Olive Garden.
author: John L.

description:
It saddens me to see so many unflattering reviews of Osteria. I've been a number of times when I'm in San Francisco on business and every time I come out raving.

Every time I go the service, food and ambiance is exceptional, and I look at Osteria as an oasis for this tired road warrior. When I go out to eat, I do so alone, so it's not the most fun experience, but when I'm there I always have a good time.

I've never ordered anything that I didn't enjoy, the servers make me feel at home and the owner is a wonderfully sweet woman.

It really is one of my favorite Italian restaurants anywhere. It has a great family feel in the ambiance and staff. The food isn't too heavy or too light, and the deserts are amazing.

Based on my experiences there it's a no brainer... go, have a good time and enjoy a great meal.
author: Max S.

description: Wonderful service, and authentic Italian food. I eat here twice a week! Ignore the bad reviews b/c the staff here makes you feel like you are fresh off the boat just like the owners.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Great customer service!!!  Real good linguine and clams!! And a really good open environment!!!

We were treated as if we were their first ever customer, or at least that is how they made us feel.  Imagine a party of 5 coming in your restaurant at 5:30pm on a Saturday without reservations.  Yeah, that was us... Before they even committed to seating us, we were given a dose of that lost art called  customer service.   Based on their kind approach and their attention to our need, I would have still written this review even if they could not have seated us.  However, we were fortunate, and they made room for us, and  treated us as if we were one of the their regulars.

Bottom-line -- Great service...and really good pasta...the coffee and cheese cake was pretty good...Great service!!!
author: Ron B.

description:
I absolutely love Osteria. I have been going there for years, and have always experienced consistent, friendly service and delicious meals. This is a cozy, neighborhood place that has its "regulars" (including me), who dine there often and are known by the staff.  However, even if you are not a regular, they will always greet you with a smile and make you feel welcome. Their ingredients are fresh and tasty and are presented pleasingly.

It seems like a lot of the reviewers have criticized the older age of Osteria's patrons or its less-than-trendy atmosphere. That is exactly what I love about this restaurant, and what I sometimes loathe about the "hipper" spots in other neighborhoods. I like that folks don't come here to see or be seen, but to have a great meal in a comfortable atmosphere.
author: Nicole M.

description:
