We had a belated date night there last Friday. Although the ambiance was lovely, the food was OK. We got dressed as that was what was indicated by the times I have walked by, and when we got inside, lots of jeans. Ahhh hate that mix match dress code. 

Anyway, we had the shrimp w/ pesto like sauce and hearts of palm. Which was great, bu my shrimp mountain was frozen in the middle. Major bummer as it was good. I had the eggplant parm and the beau had veal. Both very good, but the lemon cheese cake was where it's at. Soooo good, delicacy and creamy. 

Would I run back, probably not, but at least we have another Italian option in the neighborhood.
author: Nicole F.

description:
Well I came here on the recommendation of my best friend from high school David who was in town with his wife.  He chose the spot and I am always open to new places so was excited to try something else in this neighborhood since I don't get out there that much.

Osteria is a nice little spot with friendly service and very neighborhood feel to it.  Seemed like many of the diners knew each other as evidenced by bottles of wine being bought for each other and convo after their meals.

I'd say the food was pretty good but not unforgettable.  I'm not an expert on Italian but I have had some memorable meals at Delfina and A16 and Osteria wasn't quite at that same level for me.

There's nothing wrong at all but it just didn't have that extra special-ness.  It was a Tuesday when I went so definitely not a big night and there were just a few other groups in there.
author: Gene X.

description: It is with great sadness that I give this two-star review as we have been going here fore years. Food and atmosphere are fantastic however the poor service at our recent trip to Osteria was unforgivable - servers were friendly but woefully inattentive. We were seated on Valentine's night at 8:45pm. Halfway through our meal, our waiter sat down at a back table, began eating a dinner of his own, and completely forgot about us. Normally this would not have been a problem if other servers had picked up the slack, but we were left for over 20 min without anyone to ask for water refills, bread, more drinks, etc. We paid $65 a piece for the prefix and expected more by way of service. Was a complete buzzkill on an otherwise nice evening.
author: Russell M.

description:
Really nice place, but it is expensive and it has the fancy style feeling on it. 
The waiters were nice, but they were all over the place running from corner to corner. 
Food was good but nothing special... I liked the family owned feeling on the restaurant.
author: jaime b.

description: Years ago I lived in this neighborhood.  This past weekend, in San Francisco for a wedding, we stayed at the Laurel Inn and walked up the street for dinner at Osteria.  It was great  Wonderful service, food was great, really a terrific neighborhood restaurant.  I would definitely go back.
author: Stuart S.

description:
The food is always reliable at this quaint spot, and the  prices are very fair. There's rarely a significant wait, but there are always lots of happy diners inside - perfect.

I typically get the salmon, which is a bit on the lighter side - very fresh tasting. But most recently, I indulged in the tortellini della casa, which is a tortellini in meat sauce - outstanding Italian comfort fare.

The host is friendly and enthusiastic, and his servers get the job done. As one of the few restaurants in this 'hood, it pleases.
author: Kiesha R.

description:
very nice and warm atmosphia.
No.1 Italian in town !

Friendly staffs and great fods.
author: Osamu I.

description: LOVE this place! Love that you can tell this is where the natives go. Very friendly atmosphere, along with friendly fellow diners. Small and intimate. The food is always so good, and I end up taking leftovers.  I wish they had a full bar, sometimes wine just ins't enough after a looooooong week!
author: Michelle R.

description:
Osteria has to be my favorite Italian restaurant in the city. It's simple, fresh, and delicious. The service is excellent and the waitstaff is always eager to please. 

A few of our family favorites: 

1) The Gnocchi: these fluffy little pillows of tastiness are the best I've ever had. We usually go for the Gorgonzola sauce but the Pomodoro is equally good. 
2) Veal Piccata: bright and robust flavors, tender veal cutlets. 
3) Tortellini de la Casa: tortellini with a hearty meat sauce. 
4) Tiramisu: not your standard brick of cream and sugar! Osteria's tiramisu is lighter and well-balanced.
author: Vanessa K.

description: This is at least the 2nd if not 3rd review I have written about gnocchi.  But for real- the gnocchi at Osteria is sooooo good.  I like that this restaurant is super cute and nice and in a somewhat unexpected location.  Reasonably priced, and the people who work here are absolutely lovely.  Definitely make a reservation if you can because it is small, and thus fills up quickly.
author: Nora S.

description: Nice neighborhood type restaurant. I had the Caesar Salad- blah bottled salad dressing and not well tossed. For dinner I had the pasta with clams in a white garlic sauce- very nice flavor, perfect size portion. Prices very fair. Decent service.
author: A S.

description: Our favorite italian restaurant in SF. The tortellini and gnocchi are belissimo!!! Ambience is very homey and casual, no frou frou here. Just down right good italian cuisine.
author: Joanne R.

description: Osteria is a good neighborhood restaurant. The food and service are good. The gnocchi was very good. The restaurant is very loud. Recommend making reservations since it was quite crowded on a Saturday night.
author: Garrett H.

description:
This place specializes in mediocrity.

In fact, it excels at mediocrity.

Ho hum service (do you think you can get that plate down on the table OK? Could you please not spray saliva  on me as you recite the specials?)

Bad food. Bad food.  Bad food.  (well, the bread's OK)
EXTREMELY limited menu.  Veal, veal, and if you don't like that, there's veal ravioli.

Nice-ish atmosphere. Good intentions. But doesn't Osteria mean they serve oysters?
They don't.  I think that might be beyond them.

But really, it's all pretty clueless.  In a town of a zillion Italian restaurants 
and quite few amazing ones, it's just plain hapless to be as yuck as this place
Just the other night, I found a spot FAR  better (yea), for the same price range.

There  is an ilk that patronizes this place (accustomed to eating at Applebee's), and as for me, never again.  Dey ain't got no clayusss.
author: harmonia b.

description:
Some of the best Italian food in Laurel Heights. It's authentic, small, homey, clean, overall always a pleasant dining experience. Large helpings, dress nicely, and enjoy how magically tender they make their chicken. 

The staff is so very friendly. My bf and I walked in once after a long bike-ride looking like a pair of total ragamuffins with no reservation on a Saturday night. They sat us asap and treated us with such kindness. It's not a toddler-oriented place, but the true gentleman of Osteria tolerated my rambunctious niece and nephew with great patience. No disaffected 'hip' young waiters here! 

Great for to-go dinners, always healthy vegetarian options, good wines, a little on the heavy side- may want to split stuff.
author: R J.

description: Came last week with my girlfriend and had a delicious meal. She had the veal with mushrooms, while I chose the prawns in a creamy garlic sauce.. Both came with an assortment of vegetables that were tender and perfectly seasoned. We shared dessert, a chocolate-hazelnut custard with a caramel sauce that blew us away. In addition to the great food, we experienced great service. Will definitely return.
author: Robert B.

description:
Was introduced to Osteria by a family friend and decided to give it a shot.  Overall, really pleased.  The service was very friendly, the meal was nicely presented and perhaps most importantly, the food was hot when served.

Is Osteria a 5-star place?  No and it's not trying to be.  It's a very clean, friendly and reasonably priced neighborhood restaurant in a nice area of San Francisco.

I'll definitely go back when in the mood for a casual and satisfying meal and a good glass of wine.
author: Robert N.

description:
I have to agree that this was a pleasant surprise for Laurel Heights.  The ladies and I enjoyed a nice pre-movie meal here and will definitely be back for more.  

We started with a nice, reasonably priced bottle of the Vermentino and the antipasto plate, which was fresh and filling.

I am a huge fan of gnocchi and try to get it at any restaurant where anyone says they "specialize" in it.  Even at the very best restaurants in North Beach was I disappointed.  However, Osteria was a different story.  Their gnocchi were like little pillows of pleasure in my mouth!  Heavenly.  They were also very accommodating with switching the sauces, which allowed me to pair the pancetta, cream and peas with my pleasurable pillows : )  Everyone else agreed the dish was great, as was the special of the evening- porcinis, tomato-cream sauce & sun-dried tomatoes (which they also gladly substituted gnocchi).

After all that indulgence, the bill only came out to $82.  I'd gladly pay more for such a wonderful night out.
author: Tara G.

description:
Don't eat here.

(unless you have blue hair, dentures and no tastebuds -- if that's your deal, this spot's for you -- oh, probably best if you can't hear, either, since it's noisy)
author: C'est La V.

description:
Great Caesar's ghost, the gnocchi at this place is incredible. Imagine if the contents of a divine down comforter were enveloped in a rich gorgonzola cream sauce -- except that sounds gross.  Trust me, it was delicious.

I made it clear I was just a working stiff on my dinner break and the service was prompt and courteous.  The room warm and friendly and not at all geriatric -- the crowd was mixed ages, if a bit tonier that what I'm used to.  The staff was chatty without being invasive.
author: Tailypo W.

description: I went in very Hungry and you know when you are hungry typically anything is great food. But it was terrible. Also the price was way to high and it took to long.
author: rsa s.

description: good tortellini and wine. good bread, but not enough of it. pretty good service. great music and atmosphere for a monday night. I would go back.
author: Chancelor D.

description: I think some of the people who have rated this low have mistaken it for another restaurant.   Hands down my favorite Italian restaurant in SF.  Having lived in the City for over 10 years and in the area most of my life, before moving down south, whenever I come home I make a point to set a reservation.  It's just good food served by people who care.  The same cast of servers is there every time I've been in over the last five years -- that tells you something.  There is no pretentiousness and the prices are more than fair.  It's a great neighborhood joint with a family feel.
author: Greg B.

description:
Great Food---not "scenester"--but Great Food!

Okay, so the vibe isn't hip or trendy, but the food is amazing. Just went to Osteria last night. I had done my research in advance and wasn't impressed by the wine list so I opted to bring my own bottle of '97 Barolo. At $15, the corkage fee is well below the outrageous price that other SF restaurants charge.

We started with the prosciutto dish and shared the radicchio salad---the dressing on the salad was perfect. Oh, and the bread and olive oil were both fresh and aromatic.

We then moved on to our entrees. She had the gnocchi was some of the best either of us have had in the city. I opted for the spinach pasta (Tagliarini Contadina) with chicken and shitake mushrooms in a tomato sauce. This dish was incredible. The pasta was fresh and cooked to perfection and the sauce was not overbearing, but instead highlighted the fresh pasta and the other ingredients. Both our appetizers and entrees were recommended by our waiter and he was spot on.

The service at the restaurant was excellent. We had a two hour meal and were allowed to enjoy our wine without being rushed through the courses. We ended with the tiramisu, which I wouldn't consider the best I've ever had---but it was decent. 

Overall, this was a great dining experience and you just can't beat the prices for such high quality food. I will definitely be returning to Osteria to try the other enticing dishes on the menu. 

Please keep in mind, this is NOT a wine bar. . .it's a full service restaurant. So, for those of you who want to sip wine and don't want to eat---well, there are many other options not too far from the Vogue theater (Nektar, Terzo etc.).  

So be open minded, give this place a try and don't be so bothered by the "older" crowd. After all, it's about the food and not the other patrons, right?
author: David R.

description:
This place is great!  I really love the family owned feel of this restaurant - from staff to the customers.  Perhaps this was because I went on Sunday night.  But it doesn't matter, I'd go again just on Sunday for the same vibe.

My friend and I had the vegetable soup, poached salmon with lemon, and angel hair with fresh tomatoes and basil.  I liked the angel hair the best.  It was extremely tasty and I highly recommend this dish.
author: Alan T.

description: Gnocchi was as delicate as everyone said but the sauces on the two gnocchi dishes were on the bland side. Bolognese very good. Price very reasonable for such good food.
author: M W K.

description:
Came here with some friends - one of whom is a regular here with his wife. A quaint little bistro-like environment with very friendly servers. Everyone was always smiling and so polite. Even the patrons looked like they were in a better mood just being there.

I really appreciated the ambiance - tightly packed and plenty of energy, but never feeling like someone was peering over your shoulder or vice versa.

The food was also equally as pleasant. The carpaccio was delectable and the melon/prosciutto was very fresh. Entrees were well-sized and you definitely get your money's worth. They're packed with flavor and they carry a tone of authenticity with them. 

This place reminded my wife and I of our honeymoon in Italy. For that alone, I have to recommend Osteria. Definitely an enjoyable experience.
author: Mike C.

description: A cute & cozy place with good food at a great price.  Walking into this place, I thought it would be expensive, but it's pretty average.  The portions aren't huge, but will fill you up.  There's only street parking, but oddly enough, we found a spot right away.  I would definitely come back here.
author: Sharon W.

description:
My friend and I were seated very quickly on a bustling Sunday evening. The guy that seated us was a manager / head honcho of some sort and he was extremely friendly and polite, despite all the bustling going around.

This place is indeed a locals type of place...and in Presidio Heights/ Laurel Village, that means families and older folks. I didn't mind this at all, and despite what other reviewers said, I don't think I was treated any worse. In fact, I felt I was treated extremely well.

My friend had the eggplant parmagian, and I had meat-filled tortellini in meat sauce. (Tho if I were more decadent I'd go for the cream sauce). Fresh sourdough bread came with fresh butter (mmm, bread is only an excuse for butter), and then our server/manager gave us an extra special dipping bowl of love... a blended combination of fresh raw garlic, basil, oil, and balsamic vinegar, this sauce contributed to our eating about an extra half loaf of bread each!

Excellent value for the dishes - only a few dollars more, in some cases, than an entree from the Pasta Pomodoro chain...if you can get this homemade stuff, why ever go back to PP?

My only regret, since my belly is so insatiable, is that the portions were too normal. ;) That is, with just an entree and a few slices of bread, I was still hungry. I needed to eat a lot more bread and thankfully that green sauce helped me pack it away. I guess that's when ordering appetizers actually would make sense. ;-)
author: Liz K.

description:
I've been going to Osteria (no relation anymore to the Osteria in Palo Alto, btw) since it opened back in the early 90's. The food is excellent and consistent, the price is reasonable and the staff is always friendly.

I don't know what Faith S. means by looking like Pacific Heights people, but we are just average Joes that like good food (the sauces are all homemade...I especially love the salmon and chicken sienna) and don't live in the neighborhood BUT enjoy the neighborhood feel. I don't like trendy, yuppie restaurants.

The weekends can be crowded, so I prefer to go during the week. Osteria has stood the test of time with its consistently good food, reasonable prices and friendly service (most of the servers have been there since it opened and always remember us with a smile).
author: Angela C.

description:
I've been eating at Osteria semi-regularly for the past 3 years. The food is always good, especially for the price. My husband and I both love the tortellini with proscuitto, as well as the caprese salad.  The homemade tiramisu is the best I've ever had - although a bit much to eat by oneself. The gnocchi is also very good.

It's a good idea to have reservations here. I think they only keep a table or two open for walk-ins, especially on a weekend.  Every time we call at the last minute, they are full.  On all but one occasion, however, we have been able to walk in.  By 7:30pm, the place is packed. The crowd is often a bit older so it's not the most hip spot but it is a good meal and the staff is friendly.
author: Suzanne B.

description: I've come here 3 times total in the past 6 months. Made reservations after the first time (learned my lesson). Every time it was a great experience, with great food, great waiter, great host, and even a great busboy. I'll definately be coming back. Their desserts are yummy every time as well.
author: Katia T.

description:
I'm really surprised at all the negative reviews. My girlfriend lives down the street and we've been in a couple of times when we didn't feel like driving to other favorites.

Personally, I'm not big on Italian (Asian food's my thang,) but I've enjoyed everything I've ever had there, the staff (especially the owner) have been really nice (complimentary dish once and an after dinner cocktail another time,) and the prices are reasonable. Furthermore, I don't consider myself to be crusty; on the contrary, I'm probably one of the  younger (and sketchier) customers they have.

If you're not an ageist, check it out.
author: Jason R.

description: Weak food but great service.  My girl ordered shrimp pasta, and the shrimp were those frozen mini-shrimp dudes.  I ordered gnocchi and it was decent, but nothing to rave about.  The waiter was awesome, but the prices were way too high for the crap food they serve.
author: Ryan H.

description: We had a table reserved for five, seated right away, great waiter and service. Had the tortellini, linguini with clams, and angel hair pasta. All al dente and well presented. Stayed for tiramisu, cheesecake, cappuccino. Will come again. The salads look good too.
author: Dan S.

description: Some dishes at Osteria are really good, and some are average. The chicken special is usually good. The tiramisu is probably the best thing to get here - we sat next to a table that ordered a second one after powering through the first one.
author: Laralynne B.

description:
I've dined at Osteria twice in the past month for business dinners. Overall, the food is pretty good, the gnocchi is  *amazing*, and the desserts are sublime. 

The space itself is trattoria like, and yes the clientele tends to be older....which makes sense given its proximity to the retirement center and its location on Sacramento street near the part of Pac Heights with all of the stately mansions.   In response to Alan E.'s review about aging and us "younger folk", I would like to say that the staff at this restaurant do not seem to treat customers of diverse ages equally, and this was evident to me in both visits.  Yes, we all age, some more gracefully than others, but at this restaurant there is a clear bias of catering to the older crowd. 

 When I entered the restaurant I stood at the front waiting for someone to come greet me - somebody (the Maitre D? perhaps) came to greet me with a blank look....no hello, or even a good evening. I had to speak first, and then I was seated and the bus boy brought me some bread and water. No hello even from the assigned waiter (perhaps I would like a glass of wine while I wait for my companions?) Contrast that to the elderly party of three that came in right after me: that were greeted immediately, and kindly escorted to their table. The waiter was over in a flash with the specials of the day, with not a glance in my direction (I was seated at the next table!)

I also agree with Karen F.'s review about being too loud, such that the other customers complain. I won't get into too much detail here, but one of our party was wearing a *medical device* that evidently some other customers were complaining about. We explained the need for it. Did we receive any empathy from the Maitre D' or owner? No, none. Instead, we were asked to rectify the situation so as to appease the other diners.  Sadly, our comfort , or shall I say discomfort, was of little regard to the restaurant.

Overall, the food is good here, but the service is not. If you want to experience a fantastic neighborhood, locals only Italian street with a diverse clientele, delicious food and gracious service, go across the street to Garibaldi. You'll find it all there and more. 

As for Osteria, three stars for the food, but minus two for the service.
author: Suepattra M.

description:
Always delicious.

Osteria is a great find for a casual, intimate Italian meal. Despite the neighborhood the place is quite unassuming, the meals are respectably priced, and the atmosphere is romantic and inviting. 

I've been on several occasions and particularly love the gnocchi with Gorgonzola. Both the pasta and sauce are delicious and sumptuous, but still light. 

I've also had the prociutto di parma & melone and carpaccio appetizers, and the veal scallopini..all of which have been superb!
author: Trish C.

description: The food here is just outrageous!  Have a gnocchi dish.  They melt in your mouth.  The biggest problems are the cramped seating and the noise level.  Avoid being seated near the kitchen because the bustle as the servers swish by, and the noise in the kitchen, are very distracting.
author: Josie O.

description:
I used to really like this place years ago. However, on a recent trip I found it mediocre at best. Served me the worse Chianti I have ever had. 
However, if you feel you must try this place get there at 5PM or earlier. It is always crowded.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Osteria is a great NEIGHBORHOOD restaurant.  I'm stressing *neighborhood* because there are plenty of regulars who frequent this restaurant weekly and are, thus, treated warmly and attentively by the owner and staff.  If you come more than once or twice, chances are you will be remembered and treated just as familiarly as the regulars.  If you come only once, you'll still be treated well.

Before you assume that the older clientele are treated better merely due to their age, consider the fact that you are visiting a restaurant in a neighborhood where locals actually live, shop and eat.  Many of these patrons ARE older folks, but most of them have lived in the neighborhood a long time and are fixtures at Osteria.

Come here with blinders on if you need to, but come you must!

The owner told me that the spinach pasta is the only pasta that is actually "fresh", so I order that most of the time as my main dish.  If you ask, they'll use whatever sauce you want on whatever noodles you want ... even if the sauce is not on the menu.  

Once, I asked the owner if he would ever bring back the olive, caper, anchovy, pepper and lemon sauce, and he offered to go back into the kitchen and make it for me himself.  How many restaurant owners would do that?

As you've heard from others, the gnocci really IS spectacular.  Get it with the gorgonzola, cream and pine nuts and save some bread to wipe up your place.

The linguini with fresh tomatos and clams is indescribably perfect.  It's not at all too briny as one might expect of a clam dish, the tomatoes are so sweet and ripe and the pasta is cooked to a perfect al dente and heaped seductively on your plate with clams, tomatoes and garlic hidden in every forkful.  I'm drooling now.

The artichoke bottoms with shrimp and the caprese are my favorite appetizers.  The basil sauce that is served atop the artichoke shrimp dish could stand to be lightened up a bit ... perhaps with a squeeze from a lemon wedge? ... nevertheless, it's a great starter.

If you need a sweet finish to your meal, the crema caramella (grand marnier custard with caramel sauce) is a good choice.  There are several others to choose from if custard's not your thing.

SUGGESTIONS:  Call ahead and make a reservation to be safe.  It's hard to say what nights you may end up waiting.  As I said before, it's a neighborhood place so there are plenty of nights when couples show up with their entire brood and you have to wait for a table to free up.  Other times, there's no wait at all if you just show up.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Delicious little Italian eatery in a sea of non-restaurant commercial zoned establishments.  I have to admit I caved and ate the gnocchi per several yelpers; and it was excellent.

Extra points for any place that automatically bring me bread and olive oil.
author: Nelson A.

description: I've been going to Osteria for years and was first introduced to it by my grandparents (they would frequent a few times a week!). It's a great neighborhood spot that I would highly recommend - good food, good service, reasonable prices, small-ish space and quite a relaxed atmosphere. Have had a good meal on every occasion which is why I keep going back!
author: Anne S.

description:
This is our favorite neighborhood restaurant. There is nothing pretentious about the food but it is well made and tasty. We go there often when we feel like having a good pasta fix. We recently moved to the neighborhood and had dinner there the night we moved. They have been very friendly and welcoming to us. From reading other people's reviews, this is not everybody's experience, perhaps it has to do with the fact we go there regularly, who knows?
Anyway, I love their gnocchi! They are addictive, so it is hard for me to order anything else. My husband gets the special  anytime it is a vegetarian pasta and has never been disappointed. A lot of families go there with their kids, but there is no wild running around or screaming. It just reinforces the comfortable neighborhood restaurant atmosphere.
They serve good desserts too. The creme caramels and alike are delicious.
author: Elsa T.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed my dining experience at Osteria.  

I started dinner with the proscuitto and melon.  Very good.  I love proscuitto so if it's not up to par, I'd let you know.  

For my entree, I had the gnocchi with pomodoro sauce.  It was Fantastic.  The gnocchi was large and tasty.  The sauce was garlicy but not overpowering.  My mom had the tortellini with meat sauce.  Hers was really good too.  

The people that worked at Osteria were nothing but extremely friendly and welcoming.  I'll definitely come back.
author: Angie C.

description:
This was an interesting place to go to, especially since my friends and I are not over the age of 60 .. My roommate had celebrated her b-day here and there was probably 10 of us, laughing, joking around and talking. We found out that we were being rude and many of the old folks were telling us to be quiet.. VERY RUDE!!  Anyways, we made a joke out of it and laughed it off... 

If you like the older crowd, go for it... just don't talk to loud they might have a stroke or something.. 

I really liked their gnocchi, its really good, it melts in your mouth good.. i would usually have them at other restaurants and they would taste chewy and under cooked...I heard that their desserts were good.. The place is nice and homey and the painting on the walls are nice to look at.
author: Karen F.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up to 4.

I've been let down by some Italian restaurants in the city, pleased with others, but we keep returning to Osteria's comfortable setting. It's not as fancy or creative as some of the alternatives, but it has so far been the most consistent.

We have yet to be let down, but some of our favorites include the creamy tortellini, spinach pasta with bay shrimp, calamari steak (quite unique - and tender!), any of the veal dishes, the minestrone, and most of the appetizers, especially the bay shrimp with hearts of palms. It's not the best Italian I've ever had, but it's always good and, as it's right down the street, we will remain regulars for a long time.

Negatives: cramped, and it's time to update the decor.

There's also an Osteria in Palo Alto that's pretty good. Same menu, but not all the dishes are prepared quite as well (I was especially disappointed that the spinach pasta with shrimp was very much not up to par). Also, the staff at the Palo Alto location has a reputation for being rude with good reason. They were very unpleasant to our guest last time. But their dining room is less crowded, which is nice.
author: Veronica L.

description:
It was a weekday and hubby and I didn't want to cook so we walked over to Osteria and hoped and prayed they had a table open at 7:00 p.m. on a Thursday. We lucked out and passed all of the Reserved tables and got a table in the back.

We got the prosciutto with melon ($8.75) and that is always delicious. My husband and I both ordered a salad. I had the salad with radicchio ($6.75) and there was nothing special about it. Hubby had spinach salad ($6.75) and he really liked it. We hadn't eaten greens in forever so the salads were devoured for lack of nourishment.

For entrees I had the gnocchi in tomato and basil sauce - DELICIOUS! The gnocchi was like little balls of heaven. So light, so tasty, so yummy! Hubby had a special which was pasta in a similar tomato sauce - equally delicious. The pasta was a bit oversalted but I LOVE salt, so it wasn't all that bad. 

This is a great neighborhood restaurant. You could tell there were a lot of regulars there. By the time we left, a little past 8 p.m., the place was emptying out. 

I also love their website and the way you view their menu. You can turn the pages of the menu - pretty cool.
author: Wendy B.

description:
When I was younger, I used to love Italian food. Then my tastes matured and I became a fan of Indian, Thai, Mexican, Chinese, Ethiopian, Senegalese, Cambodian, etc. and had no room in my life for Italian.

The other night I stopped in here with a friend while waiting for our movie to start across the street, and I was pretty impressed. There was a wide enough range of prices -- if I remember correctly, I could have ordered something for as little as $9, or for $18 or more. I settled on the linguine and clams for $13. I got a reasonably filling portion and really enjoyed it, while my friend had the tortellini in cream sauce with prosciutto, which I, of course, loved because it tasted like bacon.

As I was tearing my bread, I knocked over my glass and spilled water all over the floor -- before I got a chance to even react, three waiters were on the job. They were really polite about my mistake.

After our main course, I had the hazelnut custard, which I loved, and an accompanying muscat wine that was probably the best I had ever tasted.

Basically, this restaurant provides high-class service and flavor for a middle-class price.
author: Amy Z.

description:
You haters are crazy.  This place is consistently good... seriously.  Ok, so they clientele is probably on the retirement age side, but its cozy and the staff is so nice and funny.  Food is tasty and its a good value.  

Carpaccio, veal, pastas... all MMMM... delicious.
author: Mary S.

description:
I've gone to the restaurants nearby so many times and always avoided this place--and if I recall correctly, the owner of a nearby restaurant was the one who said "you gotta try it".  I like that neighborhood support so off I went.

I swear the owner (17 years, he's usually in the kitchen) swoops in (not eerily...swoop makes it sound bad) on newbies...or maybe that is just everyone under 70, based on the other reviews.

I think I was actually there on a lively night b/c I though the energy, while far from "trendy", was solid.

Anyway, I went in thinking the food would be a 5 or a 6, but a quaint experience. I didn't up my expectations when learning that the linguini w/clams used canned clams but ordered it when this dish turned out to be the one that the people next door were having...the one that looked so good that said to the waiter (owner) "oooh...what are they having??".

as others have mentioned, the gnocchi is really etherial.  It's the kind of dish that makes you say, yes, I'm not surprised you've been around for 17 years.  This place has seen a lot and stood the test of time, so it must be doing something right.  It may be your father's Italitan restaurant but hey, isn't retro in?
author: Laurie A.

description:
This one is a bit difficult to summarize....the entrees were reasonably priced (shockingly so...all under $20) while the wine and salad seemed over-priced (why pay $8 for a plate of lettuce when you can get salmon for $15?). 

Yes, the restaurant was loud, and yes, the decor was dated (especially for the fashionable Sacramento St.). I dunno...guess I just expected more stylish pizazz.
author: Leah B.

description:
Somebody only gave you 1/3 of the name.  What's up with that?

Osteria Cucina Toscana is the full name.

It's *WONDERFUL*!!!

These are terrific people!  They serve terrific food!  

I'll go back in less than a heartbeat!

There's a reason for all these exclamation points!  They earned them!

You in San Fran?  You hungry?  Go there?  You will leave full & happy!
author: Charlie G.

description:
I love this little bristo type restaurant. They have one cook, one washer, one waitress and one hostess/manager that works as a team.  It really gives you that small family restaurant feel although they are obviously not related.

The roasted pork is what i usually have and comes with a milk sauce which sounds a bit weird, but it tastes like cheese.  I would stay away from the penne bolognese.  The sauce has a ragu vodka sauce taste to it.  I'm not even sure if thats a real product, but its what pops in my head. :]
author: Brian D.

description:
This is our neighborhood Italian spot.  The service is friendly and genuine, and the food is always delicious.  I bring my parents here when they are in town and my dad always, always loves it.

The crowd is generally older, so if you want dinner at 6:30 or 7:00 it's going to be packed.  Wait a little later until the older folks are sleeping (8:30)!
author: brittany z.

description:
One of my top three Italian restaurant favorites (Ideale and Marcello's are my other fav's). I agree that an older crowd frequents Osteria, but I dine for the quality of the food not the scene.

If you are a fan of gnocchi Osteria makes the best in San Francisco hands down. I also enjoy the artichoke bottoms filled with shrimp served with a delicious green goddess dressing. 

If you want great Northern Italian food at a reasonable price, Osteria is a great selection.
author: Michael P.

description: My hunny and I ended our trip in San Francisco with dinner here.  We had reservations promptly at 5pm (which is when they opened).  The place was quiet at first and within a half hour or so filled up quite nicely.  The establishment has a very comfy feeling to it, it almost felt like having dinner at home with family.  Staff was wonderful.  Food was delicious.  We will definitely be in again!  Thank you!!
author: Dee L.

description:
Authentic, delicious Italian food.  
The linguini with clams is fantastic!  Always a treat when the family gets together at one of our favorite Italian spots.
author: G W.

description:
Overall very disappointed with both food and service.

We arrived on time for a Friday night reservation for four, but the other couple from our party were stuck in traffic. The host and waiter were both rude, and the host repeatedly asked us specifically where our friends were at the current time (somewhere on highway 101?!).  Initially they refused to seat us and said "We usually don't seat partial parties." This would have been fine if they had been nice about it (hey, we understand) and especially if the restaurant was busy, but there were several empty tables at 730 on a Friday night. They ultimately did seat us when we said we wanted to order wine and appetizers, and our friends arrived 15 minutes later. The restaurant never filled throughout the entire evening. 

The food: Shrimp and artichoke appetizer - cold baby shrimp, artichoke heart, sauce and bed of lettuce. Good but nothing special. Friends had minestrone soup and a salad - also average. For dinner we had gnocchi and veal (two ways). All was average but definitely nothing special. 

Dessert was the only highlight of the meal - hazelnut chocolate cake and tiramisu were both delicious. 

Service continued to be sub-par throughout the evening, and at 10pm when there were still two other tables of diners a waitress said "We are going home now," to get us to leave. We will not return. This experience was overall so bad it inspired me to join Yelp and write my first-ever review...
author: Kelly H.

description: I walk by Osteria at least twice a day, and each time I would wonder why I hadn't eaten there yet. That finally changed this past Saturday, when I brought some visiting family in for dinner. The decor may be a bit dated, and the space a bit tight, but the (very traditional) menu delivers and the service is good. I got the impression we were the only first time visitors during the entire dinner service - each new group that entered was greeted with big hellos and hugs and kisses. With customer loyalty like that you have to think they're doing something right!
author: Lindsay J.

description:
the location on sacramento is good. in a clean area. the parking isn't great, but i didn't mind the walk 3 or 4 blocks to the restaurant. 

the place is small, intimate, and elegant. a bit antiquated. clean. good lighting, not overly dim. 

the waiter was polite and subtle. he did a good job of blending in to the surroundings. i prefer for the focus of my experience to be on the food, and on who i'm with. not a waiter that tries too hard, or too little. 

the food was light and tasty. i ordered the calamari steaks and prawns. the calamari was a healthy size and the prawns were tender. the sauces used were not overpowering. lemon was used in both i believe, which gave the dishes a crisp taste. good! 

overall, a nice experience. good date place.
author: Drew H.

description:
I've eaten here twice this year, and both times I've had a great experience. The first time was when my mother was in town for a conference, and we got there about 45 minutes before the restaurant closed. We had dinner, and actually ended up staying after the restaurant closed. The waiter was very nice(he may have been the owner), and he didn't try to rush us out of the place even though it was closed.

The second time was with my GF, and again it was a great experience, fast service, and excellent food, and to top it off, we were able to get two dishes, and a glass of wine for ~$20!


Just for the record, this place has the best Gnocchi I have ever had.
author: Chris E.

description: Even though I live in this hood, I've only gone to this restaurant a couple times before and never thought to review it.  Last Monday, I went there for their new "Acoustic Bistro" (free live music always pulls me in).  When I arrived, the place was packed and there wasn't an empty table except for a 4 top. Since I was alone, I told them I would wait because I didn't want to take up a large table just for me.  There was a large fun group at one table and the host asked me if I minded being seated with them.  He checked with them and they welcomed me to their table.  I ordered the shrimp risotto and grilled asparagus.  Both were yummy.  Turns out some of people I was seated with were friends of one of the performers and were musicians as well.  They ended up having to leave a little early because one of the them was the featured performer at the Utah later that night (he gave me his CD and invited me to another show he would be performing at).  After they left, the owner came and sat at the table and chatted with me for a bit.  They are excited to have live music there and couldn't have been more accommodating.  I will definitely be going back (and love that I can walk there!).
author: Tina H.

description: A good place to eat, though I advise it for lunch over dinner. The menu is a little limited, though all of the dishes on it are very well executed. The service is friendly and it had a neighborhood feel - go in few times and I get the sense that the waitstaff will start to remember you. I do find the interior to be a bit cramped, especially if you're eating with a group, unfortunately. The prices are fair so long as you don't order wine, though salads and deserts will run up the price quickly if you indulge. Overall I'll be back, though for specific types of occasions rather than for regular dining.
author: Marie S.

description:
You know, I am disappointed, but not wholly surprised, at the reviews from my fellow diners. Disappointed because the shallow reviews of "my grandparents would love it here" to "I just can't stand the retirement vibe" really show the lack of support for restaurants that are not "uber-trendy" night-life spots. Restaurants can be good even though they don't have a waiting line of very skinny girls in low slung jeans and designer bags next to the couture grunginess of the couple with dreadlocks and a snotty hostess.  Come on, people! Does it really matter to you if the retired set eats at your favorite spot too?
To get to the food-the gnocchi is truly the best in the city.  To the reviewer who said that the place smelled bad-well, I guess you don't like garlic-the staple of ALL Italian restuarants. The garlic smell is from the wonderful marinara. No blandness here! Their wine list is good, and the service was excellent. The owner checked every table and made the rounds, welcoming people inside and saying goodbye to those of us who left. The prices were excellent!
Dear reviewers, let's remember that sometimes its ok to eat where your grandparents like to eat. It might not have disco lights, thumping house music, half naked waiters/waitresses, or a 20 page wine list, but it will have low prices, good service, and, more than likely, great food.
author: Tova S.

description: Don't go to Osteria unless you enjoy being scammed. My girlfriends and I went in to share a pre-movie bottle of wine. Upon asking the owner for a recommendation, he offered to let me taste one of the wines we were considering. He proceeded to bring us an entire bottle and uncork it -- as if we didn't know the difference between tasting a wine to decide whether to order it and tasting wine to determine whether it's corked. We weren't interested in any food, but he brought us plates "just in case" and lingered about the table insisting that we should eat something and sighing to himself. When the bill came, I noticed that we'd been overcharged for the wine. I brought it to the owner's attention and he blamed some hapless waiter even though I'd seen him handwrite the bill himself. Never again.
author: Heather F.

description: We took my grandmother for the 85th bday. We had reservations for six.  We showed up the table was ready, the service was fast and very on top of things for such a small place.  The special was Gnocci which was amazing!  For desert I had the cheese cake, it was creamy with a hint of lemon.  Overall a great experience!
author: Aaron S.

description:
Osteria is great.  We found this place about six months ago, and we've been a half dozen times since.  Always great.  Some of their pastas are hand made, but they are all delicious.  As others have said, the gnocchi is the best in the city. 

Order the fondo di carciofo con gamberetti (artichoke bottoms with shrimp) as an appetizer.  Just trust me on this one.

The wine list is quite adequate at very reasonable prices (no where else have I seen a good brunello for under $100).  While you won't find the very finest wine here, there are some very good selections.

We usually walk in or call right before, and have only run into a long wait once.

Won't break the bank.  Oh, and they take AmEx.  Complete package.
author: Tim M.

description:
Great veal dishes. The cheesecake is amazing!  Artichoke bottom with shrimp starter is also a favorite. 

Been an irregular patron for over 9 years. Cozy and warm atmosphere. Lots of neighborhood  regulars. Friendly and good service. Menu does not change, but everything is solid and good. Affordable. My go-to SF Italian restaurant for family get togethers.
author: Alison M.

description: Got there on a Thursday about half an hour before they closed. We were seated by the owner of the restaurant who is a very nice gentleman. Had a great conversation with him after our dinner was done.. Prompt service from the waiter (constant refill of drinks, bread) The food was great (reasonably priced) and we didn't have to wait long for it to be served. Would definitely go there again.
author: Andy T.

description: Best gnocchi in the city - by far. I have yet to find a place that even makes gnocchi that is competitive. It 's got a great neighborhood feel to the place. Very low key. Not good for a posh night out, but a nice place to take your parents out to dinner. The eggplant parmigana is not so good, however, so I'd recommend skipping it if you usually go for this dish (as I do).
author: Jenica M.

description: i love this place!  its one block from my place so i have been there to dine in and to order take out many times.  no matter what the circumstance is, the staff here is terrific and so is the food.  i just called to ask for a simple fettuccine alfredo which is not on the menu but ive been really craving it lately and they are totally going to make it happen.  she even said she would talk to the kitchen to make it extra delicious if thats even possible.  the point is that customer service is still alive in some restaurants in this snobby food city and i really appreciate it when it happens.  ill be sure to leave an extra tip for the extra special treatment for extra delicious fettuccine alfredo.
author: Michelle N.

description: Simply a wonderful neighborhood restaurant .  Friendly staff, warm decor, and delicious food at reasonable prices.  My favorites are the caprese salad and the veal picatta.  My daughter used to live nearby and we went there often.  Now only rarely, and it is like visiting an old best friend.
author: Clay C.

description:
Went here for the second time Sunday for a friends birthday. The food was as good as I remembered. 
The four of us shared the Antipasto Assortito,  the menu said for 2, but was plenty for us all to get at least a taste of everything. 
This time I ordered tortellini panna al prosciutto e piselli, meat filled tortellini with peas and prosciutto. The dish was perfectly portioned, just enough after all the bread and appetizer. The peas and prosciutto were nicely paired with the cream sauce and the tortellini. Everyone else got tortellini della casa, gnocchi al gorgonzola con pinole, and petto di pollo dorato alla parmigiana. The tortellini della casa was served with meat sauce and very good. The gnocchi, which I ordered the first time I visited this restaurant, is amazing. Fluffy pillows that melt in your mouth, absolutely delicious, and a must try! The petto di pollo dorato alla parmigiana, chicken parmesan, was nicely done and served with vegetables. 
For dessert they brought out some tiramisu for the birthday girl and we also ordered crema gianduia. The tiramisu was fantastic and flavorful, no skimping on soaking the sponge layer. And the crema gianduia, a chocolate hazelnut custard was delicious. WIth both of these it was just enough for us to share and round out our meal.
author: Emily P.

description: I just have to jump in and defend this restaurant against some of the poor Yelp reviews... this is one of my favorite neighborhood spots. Granted, on some nights you might be the only one under 50, but that's part of the charm. Order anything that's "della casa," like the house salad with their special mix of Green Goddess dressing (how retro is that??) or pasta with the house sauce. My guests have always been impressed.
author: Shannon L.

description: Love this neighborhood gem and its gnocchi (they're nice and soft and just melt in your mouth).  This is a nice intimate spot where you can hear your companion, sit in flattering lighting and pay a reasonable price for your food.  They'll also accommodate take out orders.
author: She-Ra ..

description: This is just an adorable little place.  Great intimate atmosphere, great service, decent food.  We had a lovely dinner there with Mel and Al (thanks guys for introducing this to us).  I would come here again for: random romantic dinner with sig other, girlfriend catch up dinner, close family member in town visit.
author: Ann F.

description: Great place. Extremely friendly staff. Good food. Easy to get to on public transit. I had a pasta dish with seafood. Loved it. Check this place out for sure.
author: Jay C.

description: I've been here 4 or 5 times, and the food is consistently good. The service is wonderful. Great neighborhood atmosphere.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I've been on two dates here.  I also took my 16-year old brother who was visiting from out of state.  He loved the gnocchi.  We shared the mocha almond ice cream torte.  Some of my other favorites are the spinach salad and shrimp scampi.  Bring a big appetite... there are so many excellent creations to sample at this place!

As Osteria is physically tucked back on a quieter part of Sacramento Street, a night sharing Italian food makes this intimate trattoria a place of many memories!  The house red wine is cheap and pairs well with just about anything...
author: Lindsay M.

description: Food is excellent. Always has been. Service is good, though depends on the individual. Lots of conversation takes place, thus the feeling of energy, which we like. You may find better food somewhere, but Osteria is consistent with its food and we know what we will get, each time we eat there. We have never had a bad experience here or at Osteria in Palo Alto.
author: Average Guy R.

description: A great destination spot.. only 20 mins from Novato!   We've been there twice.   Alex was our favorite waiter.. he has moved on.. and we have yet to be back.  A mid week night out .. drive thru West Marin.. stopping in Pt. Reyes.. a little fog..   Not much better!
author: Sean R.

description:
basically the best Italian food in the area, Osteria has the vibe of a neighborhood restaurant with quality of a bistro, 
you really can't go wrong with the gnocchi with tomato sauce and basil, or the special gnocchi with cream, tomato and peas, 
I was a bit disappointed with the deserts, the tiramisu is great, but the sorbes where mediocre (I tried the vannila and raspberry).
author: Ira S.

description: This a great neighborhood spot.  The food is great and very reasonably priced.  I took the folks here when they were visiting and they were quite impressed.  I had the spinach pasta with chicken and damn was it good.  Dad loved his chicken special and Mom was a fan of her pasta with shrimp.  The service is friendly and warm and its a comfortable, casual place to go when you just need a good meal without the flair.
author: Miss M G.

description: A great neighborhood restaurant with wonderful service and yummy Italian food. My family and I go there all the time. I always get the gnocchi with marinara sauce and mozzarella cheese on top, which is fantastic. My mother loves the veal piccata and my dad loves the calamari steak. The waiters are super friendly and it is always an enjoyable dinner. They are closed on Mondays.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
It's just not that good. It's not bad, but, c'mon basic Italian should be so much better.  The gnocchi seems like it is not homemade - it's mushy and bland. The basic pomodoro sauce is unremarkable. The minestrone is tasty and passable.

I been there twice. The first time was with a friend who made reservations. I had the soup and gnocchi. Gnocchi sucked, the sauce was good. The second time I dropped by with my partner and a friend on a Saturday night at 9pm. The waiter (owner?) asked if we had reservations even though it was late and there were 5 empty tables. We thought he was joking since the place was deserted, so we laughed. He was serious and seemed offended. He grumbled that he would have to check his reservation list to see if he could fit us in. He proceeded to walk around the restaurant several times for the next 5 minutes, checking NOTHING, and then he returned and seated us. We continued laughing since it was obvious that the 5 minute wait was punishment since we didn't have reservations. What the hell is it with San Francisco and reservations? Why can't you just stroll by a place - and when it is EMPTY - be seated promptly and courteously?

On this visit I had penne that was bland and flavorless and my partner had a fish special that was passable. My friend ordered the gnocchi and it was definitely not homemade once again.

When the check arrived the sour puss waiter/owner suddenly got friendly.

We won't be going again.
author: Marcia B.

description: Cute little old school, non-trendy neighborhood Italian restaurant.  Gnocchi is one of their specialties, but I am especially enamored with their linguini and clams.  Reasonable food and wine prices too.
author: Roy N.

description: Osteria is a small family run place, with good food.  The waiters were excellent.  The person that greets you upon entering is best described as snooty.  We did not have a reservation, but it did not matter since the place was not half full.  If you go, get a table away from the front door and the blast of arctic air that washes over you whenever the door opens.  The waiter entertained our kids with two magic tricks, a nice touch.  The lemon cheesecake was out of this world.
author: Chad M.

description: I guess, as my husband mentioned, for American standard is good (he is American, I am European). It's been a long time since I felt so bad spending 60$ on food. I had the butter lettuce and it wasn't fresh, brownish, wet and the dressing was very heavy. It almost felt like garlic mayonnaise. I went there for gnocchi, I have read a lot of reviews about their gnocchi. Overcooked to a point that were already melted, the Gorgonzola sauce was super salty and too peppery. My husband had prosciutto and melon. The melon wasn't fresh but mushy. We ended up with same strawberry grand Marnier sauce dessert and this one was very disappointed as well. No flavour. No point to go back. The prices on tehi website are not the same ones that are on the menu'.
author: Biemme B.

description: I love love the past bolgnese.  I die for fresh monade pasta and they are best.  So cozy and inviting gota try it!
author: Karen S.

description: Really solid food. I was pleasantly surprised by the presentation and quality of every dish that was presented to my table. Service...kinda odd. We couldn't tell who our waiter was and we waited for our bottle of wine for almost 20 minutes. Not a deal breaker, but definitely noticeable error in our service. i would come back because the food was so good.
author: Shannon C.

description: I like the casual ease of this place.  The food is alway good, and the service very neighborhood-y.
author: Barbara M.

description: I liked this place.  It's probably my addiction to homey neighborhood Italian restaurants, so if you like that kind of thing you'll like this place, too.  I thought the food was okay, and it was definitely reasonably priced.  I took out-of-towners here and we had a really nice time.
author: Anna S.

description: Normally, I wouldn't publicly say how much I love this restaurant, because I really like it as an undiscovered neighborhood gem... but when I saw the low scores, I had to speak up.  Agreed, this place is not about the "scene," but the food is amazing & very reasonable.  Standouts on the menu are the artichoke/shrimp appetizer, gnocchi & the calamari steak - which is calamari unlike any you've had before.
author: Ken H.

description: Sallow Italian food served up to sallow customers in a sallow room by sallow staff.  Pick something else, anything else, even if you have to go home and have Jif.
author: Kevin S.

description: Great neighborhood restaurant-- really cozy.  Service was warm and unrushed.  The food was good as well-- especially my unbelievably fluffy gnocchi with pink sauce (pink sauce = marinara + gorgonzola; not on the menu but they'll make upon request).  After dinner, you can catch a movie at the Vogue which is right across the street, or go down a block to G Bar for a post-dinner drink.
author: shoba d.

description: Basic italian food. We went for mothers day and it was very loud, my cesear salad was just ok (kind of hard to have an ok cesear I thought) but I did like my entree which was tortillini's with cream, peas and ham which is how it wound up with 2 stars instead of 1.
author: Jenifer B.

description: I really really wanted to like this place 'cause it looks like my Grandma's place and it's really close to my house but I can't.  I just can't.  I might send my grandparents there...
author: Cosmolicious L.

description: This is a solid Italian eatery in Pacific Heights. The pasta is fresh and the tasty sauces aren't too heavy. This place is better than the chains, but not quite what I had in Italy. It's still very good, though. The place attracts an older neighborhood aesthetic, but surprisingly....it's not pretentious. Aaahh! I like to hit this spot every few months and each time they are consistent. Their table service is good, parking is easy and the prices are pretty reasonable. This is my "diamond" in the rough Pac Heights.
author: Fil L.

description:
L 'Osteria has been here for years, and it really is one of the Best Dining values in San Francisco. The restaurant is always busy...a very good sign. We don't come in often enough, but when we do I always end up ordering the same thing,, 
The best salad on Planet earth is right here...Artichoke bottoms stuffed with bay shrimp served on butter lettuce and topped off with a green godess type dressing...oh my god...this is good...
The gnocchi in a Gorgonzola cream sauce with pine nuts , it is out of this world. This is the worlds best gnocchi (in my opinion). they are light, fluffy and melt in your mouth, that along with the Gorgonzola cream sauce....The fish dishes offered are always executed well...but I need my gnocchi fix and this is the place for it... 
Desserts are great as well... 
The staff is just great, very friendly and they've all been here for years, the service is just excellent...for a neighborhood Italian restaurant it doesn't get any better than this....
author: Jim R.

description: Absolutely solid, immediately put into the rotation of places to enjoy again sometime soon.
author: T O.

description: I, unlike some people, LIKE going places that have old people.  To me it says "reasonably priced, quiet, dependable, early dinner rush, smells slightly like diapers".  Okay, so this place had all of it but the diaper smell.  I had a class across the street at 7 PM, walked in at 6:10 on a Tuesday night, was seated right away, and was eating 10 minutes later.  By the time I left the place was packed.  Definite neighborhood vibe to it...like the older patrons come to order the specials every week since they've eaten everything else on the menu a million times.  Pasta portions were medium sized and I did need to eat some bread to fill up.  I had the spinach pasta with chicken and mushrooms.  Tasty.
author: Rachel W.

description: i agree with Janet... the neighboorhood is great becaue there is so many things you can do around that area. The food itself was pretty good; It was filling and I would definitely go there again.
author: Judy M.

description: I ordered classic Italian dish clam pasta, and it turned out the clam was from a can. If I had known this earlier, I will never have ordered in a restaurant. Very low rating here, don't bother.
author: Wen L.

description: Great neighborhood Italian.  Staff is great, nice atmosphere, very reasonable prices for the neighborhood.
author: Michael L.

description: Staying at the Laurel Inn for the Christmas holiday and huge fans of Italian food this was a natural. Made Reservations for 3 @ 7PM and we were seated in a nice cozy private little section to enjoy what was about to happen. This is a very small local neighborhood bistro. Loved the menu selections starting with the Antipasti through the Zuppa and Ensalada and Pasta Courses.  Entrees' of course are superb. This kind of dining you will enjoy slowly and one course at a time. The food is to be savored and enjoyed. Don't expect huge portions this is not that kind of restaurant.  Perfect selections and portions sizes to enjoy while conversing with your company. Dolci of the homemade variety rounded out our evening. Wonderful neighborhood feel. Wait staff very friendly and accommodating.  Wish we lived in SF so we could become regulars. It is that good. Great value too. We will be back. Enjoy....
author: Bob M.

description: I like what I had which was a spinach pasta with shrimp. Its a nice little place. 4 people about 65 dollars. Very Welcoming!
author: LaLa n.

description: Great casually elegant Pacific Heights restaurant without the "attitude".  We're hooked on the Artichoke Bottoms w/Shrimp & the "very tender" Calamari Steak sauted in Lemon Butter...Yum Yum!
author: toni u.

description: We love, love, love Osteria!!!  Wonderful Italian fare without the frills. The Sienna Chicken and Ravioli are fantastic as are their regular staples, Tortellini Dela Casa and Calamari Steak.  Dominic, Andy, John, Raul and the rest of the staff make you feel right at home.  Definitely our favorite restaurant!
author: Felice A.

description: This is the perfect neighborhood Italian restaurant. The prices are totally reasonable the service is super nice and the food is consistently good.  I especially like the spinach pasta with chicken tomatoes and mushrooms and the veal scaloppini
author: Lauren H.

description: Love this corner neighborhood spot.  There are not a ton of great places to choose from up in presidio heighs but this one consistently hits the spot.  I would recommend making a reservation, especially on the weekend.  Best gnocchi in the city.  I love all their salads: the caprese with green goddess dressing, the spinach salad with peanuts and the butter salad are all divine.  My husband is a big fan of the steak carpaccio  The tortellini is also delicious.  If they have a chicken special, get it.  It's always good.  The only thing I did not love there is the pasta with cream and peas.  Everything else I've tried has been great.  Meals are portioned right which allows them to keep the prices reasonable.  We usually get out of there around $80 with salads, entrees and wine.
author: Janet L.

description:
A lively yet supremely comfortable neighborhood place - with service that makes you feel like home yet is executed with professionalism.  

A fantastic people-watching spot of the who's who of Presidio Heights and Pac Heights - I've spotted Robin Williams with family and Dede Wilsey here (separately). 

Comfort food abound:  linguine alle vongole (the best in town), veal scallopini with mushrooms or piccata, and incredibly light fluffy homemade gnocchi with gorgonzola that is a must-share dish to begin with.
author: Michaela S.

description: The prices and qualify of food are reliable; you get a great bargain across the board.  Good gnocchi, fish, and salads.  The staff is friendly, engaging, and flexible about substitutions.  (There is one co-host or waiter that we find a bit strange; Dominic is the best!)  Several mentioned older diners at this restaurant and they are right.  Just like any neighborhood restaurant that caters to its regular customers, the older folks eat early and the younger ones dine on the later side.  If you are looking for good, affordable Italian food in the Pres Heights area, this is the place.
author: M.D. L.

description: this is a good italian restaurant! my teacher, who recently came from italia, told me about this restaurant which had food that actually resembled the one he used to eat in italia soooo i went and it was delicioussssss. i have never tried italian food so good as this.
author: Carol i.

description: nice neighborhood restaurant.  the food is good but not amazing.  there's a pleasant, casual, neighborly feel to the place, with a good number of regulars and families.  the servers are friendly and funny, so you may excuse the occasional lack of attentiveness. we like to go here for a relaxed night out.  to me, they seem to offer a lot of comfort food; it tastes homemade in a good way.
author: Eric F.

description: Osteria is a charming little spot with friendly service and a comfortable neighborhood feel to it.   The food was high quality, and I have had some memorable meals there.  It's very cozy and a great place to take a date or someone you don't mind getting close to.
author: Amy A.

description: osteria is "our" little neighborhood place, even though we only go there every three or four months.  it is so adorable.  always full of families.  the service is friendly but a little slow--maybe because the servers are always gabbing with the regulars.  and everyone in there always seems to be a regular!  it's all part of the charm.  my husband and i have tried a few different dishes but always come back to the same two--tortellini with prosciutto and peas for him and capellini al pomodoro for me.  delicious with insalata della casa and minnestrone soup!  also, i'm not sure what brand of olive oil they use but it is heavenly.  if it wasn't so frowned upon, i'd screw the bread and drink it straight from the dipping dish.
author: kate s.

description: OMG! Everyone in here is older and super cute. Not older I want to date you Mr. Clooney but older you remind me of my grandparents and it's okay because this restaurant is so warm and charming. My BFF brought me here for dinner last week and told me that it definitely was not on and poppin but that the food was very good and inexpensive. From the moment we walked in everyone was so NICE. The host came over and immediately greeted us and told us it would be about 15 minutes or so ( which it was ). We were then seated and our server was amazing. Super friendly and knowledgeable about everything on the menu and I don't see much of this anymore so it was a treat to be taken care of. She did not skip a beat, rattled off specials, brought out meals right on time, kept checking in on us with out overstepping and always had a smile on her face. Best part was the fact that we each had an appetizer, then a salad, an entree and about 5 glasses of wine for 35.00 each.
author: Jazzelyn F.

description: Osteria is a really great little find!  I ate here for the first time last night, and I am so happy I did.  The food and service was great.  The prices are also quite reasonable.  The gnocchi was great, and my boyfriend had the Osso Bucco special, which was yummy too.  This is a perfect little Italian restaurant.
author: Amanda P.

description: I went here awhile ago with my friend prior to going across the street for a movie.  The food was AMAZING!, and I've been dying to go back ever since.  Both of our dishes were excellent!  And the service was very friendly, just a little on the slow side.  Good ambiance as well, very relaxing and cozy, and I'm hoping to bring my husband along next time for a 'date night'.
author: KG P.

description: Great authentic food with a wonderful homey atmosphere. Reminiscent of family-run Italian restaurants in the New York area.  Not at all touristy like the majority of Italian in SF.  Best Italian restaurant I've been to here.
author: Samantha G.

description: Kind of boring. Like its neighborhood, Laurel Heights.
author: Nicole R.

description: I love the food here, it's always fresh and delicious.  I have to say that the service is the only thing keeping this from being a five star rating.  The waiters aren't as friendly or attentive as I like, but the food is well worth it.
author: Rachel G.

description: Had dinner here last Friday and it was great!  We did not have a reservations, but they sat us quickly and explained the menu and specials. I had the shrimp scampi yum and my husband had the calamari  steak amazing! We would drive back just to have dinner here again.
author: Adele H.

description: It always amazes me to see how totally ignorant some of you are....this is a nice place....I wonder if you "young" folks will have the brains and good fortune to live long enough to be older so you can enjoy eating there also. You will be surprised to find that aging is inevitable...until then, enjoy your ear splitting "music", your cell phones attached to your ears, and your simplemindedness........it is probably blissful to be so ignorant....I have no way of knowing......
author: Menlo Man n.

description: Not the most hip and happening place in town but the food is GREAT!  The gnocchi is fabulous!  Another Yelper raved about it so I had to try it.  I highly recommend it.  The price for the quality of the food was pretty darn good too.
author: Marie N.

description: We went here tonight to relax and enjoy good food.  Ta-Dah!  Our favorite waiter, Domenic, was there, and so were other friendly staff people.  It wasn't crowded -- today IS Wed.!-- and we got seated right away. We have come here for years and it nearly always rates among my favorites.  (Sometimes the noise level gets me crazy. ) I adore the totellini de la casa and the spinach salad.  The mocha ice cream pie is yummy for an occasional treat!  We especially love that the food is excellent and arrives hot.  The portions are perfect-- ample but not huge.  Good food, great people, and -- as long as it isn't too crowded-- a great place for a relaxing meal.  Be cautious if it's super crowded.  It only takes 2 or 3 loud talkers to make the place seem deafening.  Also, a rez is a good idea esp. on the weekend. Definitely worth a visit, esp. if you live within walking distance.
author: Joan O.

description: This is a hidden gem! It is simple and yummy. The prices are great! I love the staff - it seems like they have been there forever which is always a good sign.
author: CC C.

description: This is one of my favorite Italian Restaurants in town. I'm Italian and I know italian food. The price is right which is why I give it FIVE stars.
author: Lorena M.

description: Yeccchhh.  The food was so disappointing!!  I had a simple pasta dish -- the pasta special of bowties with a red sauce, Italian sausage and arugula -- and it was so salty, it just about made me gag.  Didn't the cook taste it before allowing it to leave the kitchen?  Why ruin a dish like that?  Their house white California wine was downright disgusting.  Yes, we should have ordered an Italian wine, but we had a friend in from out of town, so thought California might be better.  What a bad idea. I would give it only one star, but the atmosphere is admittedly lovely.  The decor is pretty and the Italian arias and songs, playing not too loudly in the background, were nice. Still, at $40 a head for dinner, if you want a decent tasting meal, go somewhere else!!
author: Antonia J.

description: Let's just say: The Dining Experience From H-E-L-L. I went to Osteria in hopes of a lovely evening with my work colleagues and we three were s00000 disappointed because: 1. the service was terrible; I had water splashed on me by a waiter at the table next to ours; we waited and waited and waited for EVERYTHING (dare I suggest it was because we were three women??); the waitress stood at the back of the restaurant staring offf into space and taking her sweet time and there were perhaps three other tables of diners,i.e. it was not busy; and our water glasses were never refilled; and we had to remind the waitress that we had ordered wine 3 time. ...2. The food was terrible: my salmon tasted like chicken that had been soaked in salt water and it had an unpleasant-tasting and unidentifiable sauce; my colleague's soup was "terrible" and my salad had a hideous dressing on it.When the waitress picked up my plate at the end of the meal, she looked at my salmon (much more than half remained) and asked me what was wrong. When I told her it was terrible, she said "we'll get that taken off your bill." However, she came back later and said "He (the manager) can't do it. If you had not eaten it, he would have not charged you." Say, what???  Avoid, avoid, avoid.
author: mar b.

description: Love this place...Veal picata is great....long time friendly staff....butter lettuce sals good....great neighborhood spot
author: Scott W. W.

description: Okay.  My husband and I fit the profile of the 50 and older crowd and we LOVE this place!   This restaurant is unpretentious and comfortable and is such a price performer!  Our favorite entrees are the calamari and the veal piccata or scallopini.  We have two teenaged daughters and they enjoy the pasta or the grilled chicken.  Being able to walk to restaurants in the neighborhood and having the staff give you a hug as you walk in is part of the wonderful charm of San Francisco and Osteria clearly fits the bill!
author: Maureen F.

description: After reading the other reviews for this restaurant I can only conclude I've had the misfortune of dining there on off days.  I first ate there when we moved into the area several years ago and was so disappointed I vowed never to return.  Twice since I've broken my vow - most recently last month - and both times I was reminded why I avoid the place.  Slow service, excessive deference to regulars at the expense of others (we have always been placed at the worst table by the door where everyone who enters bumps you as they walk by, regulars get seating preference and their food is always served well before ours even though they arrived 20 to 30 mins after us etc) and so so food.  I last had a veal dish that was so salty it was inedible.  I have renewed my vow...three strikes is enough.
author: Dennis B.

description: This review is not about the food, which we did not have the opportunity to try, but about the unpleasant manner my wife and I were treated while waiting for a table.  We did not have reservations and the host asked us to wait while he prepared one for us.  After about five minutes, another couple (older, Asian), likewise without a reservation, walked in, and the host sat them immediately while we incredulously stared on.  After about ten minutes, we were ushered to the table everyone dreads being sat at -- you know, the one in the far reaches of a restaurant, next to the restroom.  We kindly declined the table and requested one near the door that was available and were told that it was a three-person table.  (A three-person table?)  The host then told us he would see what he could do and we waited at the door and after a few minutes of not being tended to we left.  The host had a very faux-accommodating manner about him -- the one with the fake, put-on smile.  We were very nicely dressed but appeared at least twenty years younger than the rest of the customers who belonged to the mid-fifties, monied-seeming demographic.  It kinda felt like a reverse age discrimination thing going on there.  Anyway, we walked across the street to Garibaldis where we were graciously welcomed and had an amazing meal and phenomenal time.
author: Salvatore Z.

description: This might just be the best neighborhood Italian food in town.  Everything on the menu is solid.  And I know everything is fresh and home-made as I spent an afternoon in the ktichen learning how to make gnocchi and tomato sauce from the owner.  This place does have the best gnocchi in San Francisco.  It isn't worth even ordering gnocchi in other restaurants.  You can have it with a fresh tomato basil or with gorgonzola sauce (both are exceptional). The only other place in the area that rivals is Della Santina in Sonoma.  In addition to the gnocchi, Osteria's  fresh spinach pasta with chicken that is excellent.   Another stunner is their chicken parmegiana which is made with a flatened chicken breast-- it melts in your mouth.  The nightly specials are always a treat..when the owner makes ravioli you should order them.  You can't go wrong with anything on this menu.  And save room for biscotti, those are also made by the owner.
author: Kathryn P.
